div.p: Looking Glasse FOR, Or An AWAKENING WORD TO The Superiour and Inferiour Officers, with all others, belonging to the Armies of England, Scotland, and Ireland; more especially to those, who have the least Spark of grace or Principles of true honesty remaining in them.

Wherein is set before them, and presented to the World, some Passages contained in severall of their Declarations, Remonstrances, and Engagements, &c. Speciously pretending for the just Rights and Liberties of the People, in the way of a Common wealth, opposed to Monarchy; and more especially, for the Advancement of the Kingdome of Christ, and his Saints ruling for him till he comes himself.
With some Marginall Annotations, whereby (in some measure) is manifested how evidently they are declined and turned aside from the Principles of Justice and Righteousness, therein contained.

p.hi: As also how they justifie the proceedings of those, who (in the prosecution of these principles of Justice and Righteousnesse,) shall oppose their backslidings.

q.p: Gall. 2.18. For if I build again the things which I destroyed, I make my self a transgressor.
Rom. 2.3. And thinkest thou this O man, that judgest them that do such things, and doest the same; that thou shalt escape the judgment of God.
Jer. 2.14. Is Israel a servant? is he a home born slave? Why is he spoiled?

V. 19. Thine own wickednesse shall correct thee, and thy backsliding shall reprove thee; Know therefore and see, that is is an evill thing and bitter, that thou hast forsaken the Lord thy God, and that my fear is not in thee saith the Lord God of hosts.

div.head: To the Army.
div.p: HAving perused many of your Declarations, Remonstrances, and Engagements, &c. made before the Lord and to the People in the day of our st aights, to engage him, and them unto you, and observing in your expressions therein, such specious pretences to justice and righteousnesse, and the preservation of the Peoples Rights and Liberties, in opposition to all Tiranny and Oppression whatsoever; and this in the way of a Common-wealth, or Free-state, opposed to a Monarch, or single person. As also for the advancement of the Kingdome of Jesus Chri t, and that you would endeavour to put the Power of this Na • ion, • nto the hands of his Sa • nts, t • ll he comes himself. Considering also the eminent • resence o • the Lord, the Fa ••• , Prayers, Appeals, and love of his people engaged with you, and your dread & terrour upon the enemy at home and the Nations abroad, whilest you were acted by these honest principles. I cannot but very much wonder that you should so soon forsake the Lord, and be s • ating your selves upon that foundation, and doing those very things, you so much condemned in others; and were so instrumentall to destroy. Surely that presence of the Lord, and the love of his faithfull people, as eminently withdrawing from you, since you first forsook him, and turned aside into these by and crooked paths; declares plainly (and it cannot but leave this dint • ehinde it upon your sp • rits, that your present way and practise is not good; and therefore its bests for you before it be too late (according to 2 Hos. 2.) to return unto your first husband, and walk in that good old way, wherein he shined upon you, for you cannot but acknowledge that it was better with you then, than now?

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p: I hope the subject matter of this Book needs not many words to invite thee to a se • ious view thereof, but rather expect thou art waiting for it, than now come to be questioning of it: surely it is not my delight to be raking into other mens sores, but the danger of the whole body forceth me to this Corosive, least through too much tendernesse it perish; besides, the necessity which lyeth upon all men in this juncture of time, to appear for Christ, and the Nations Freedome; and therefore thou art desired, na • rowly to peruse it, and in thy place, to be speaking, and doing, what thou canst for the truth in this day least thou come under the repr • of of the Prophet, Isa. 59.4. None calleth, for Ju •• ice, nor any man pleads for truth, &c. And let nor the feare o • man discourage thee, or the consideration of worldly relations, and engagements hinder thee, but up and be adoing, and the Lord be with thee.

div.head: A Looking-Glasse or an Awakening Word to the Superiour, and Inferiour Officers, with all others belonging to the Armies of England, Scotland and Ireland, more especially to those, who have the least spark of grace, or principle of true honesty remaining in them.
In a Declaration or Representation of the Army, tendered to the Parliament, June 14. 1647.
div.p: Page 4. (say they.)

VVE are not a meer Mercenary Army, hired to serve an Arbitrary power of State, but called forth and conjured by the several Declarations of Parliament to the Defence of the Peoples just Rights and Liberties. And so we took up arms in judgment and conscience to those ends, and have so continued them, and are resolved according to your first just desiree in your Declarations, and such principles, as we have received from your frequent informations, and our own common sense concerning those our fundamental Rights and Liberties; to assert and vindicate the just Power and Rights of this Nation in Parliament, for those common, ends premised against all Arbitrary Power, Violence and Oppression, and against all particular parties, or interests whatsoever, &c.

And truly such kingdomes as have according both to the law of nature, & Nations appeard to the vindication of their just rights, and liberties, have proceeded much higher, as our bretheren of Scotland who in the first begining, of these late differences associated in Covenant from the very same grounds and principles, having no visible for me either of Parliament o • King to countinance them, and as they were therein justified, and protected, by their own, and this kingdome also, so we justly shall expect to be, we need not mention the state of the Netherland, the Portugalls, and others all proceeding upon the same principles, of Right and Freedome, &c.

The Parlament hath declared it no resisting of Magistracy to side with just Principles and Law of Nature and Nations, being that law upon which we have assisted you, and that the soldiery may lawfully hold the hands of the Generall who will turne his canon against his Army: The Seamen the hands of that Pilot who willfully rune the ship upon a Rock (as our bretheren of Scotland argued) and such were the proceedings of our Ancestors of famous memory to the purchasing of such rights and liberties as they have enjoyed through the price of their bloud
and we both by that and the latter bloud of our deare freinds, and fellow souldiers, with the hazard of our own, do now lay claime too.

Nor is that supreme end the glory of God wanting in these cases to set a price upon all such proceedings of righteousnes and Justice, it being one witnes of God in the world to cary on a Testimony against the injustice, and unrighteousnes of men, and against the miscariage of Governments when corrupted or declining from their Origional, and Primitive glory. These things we mention but to compare proceedings and to shew that we are so much the more Justifiable, and warranted in what we do, by how much we come short of that height, and measure of proceedings which the people in free Kingdoms, and Nations have formerly practised, &c.

We are so far from designing, or complying to have an absolute, or Arbitary power fixed, or settled for continuance in any persons whatsoever, as that if we might be sure to obtaine it, we cannot wish to have it so in the persons of any whom we could most confide in, or who should appeare most of our owne opinions and principles, or whom we might have most assurance of or intrest in, but we doe and shall much rather wish, that the authority of this Kingdome in Parliament rightly constituted may ever stand and have its course, &c. which may give most hopes of justice, and Righteousnesse, to flow down equally to all, in that its ancient Chonnell, without any Overtures
tending either to overthrough that foundation of Order and government in this Kingdom, or to ingrosse that power for perpetuity into the hands of any perticular persons or party whatsoever, &c. And do also declare as to Parliaments.

That those who appeare most Righteous, and for common good having an unlimited power fixed in them dureing • ife or pleasure in time may be corrupt, and settle into parties, or factions, therefore the only way to provide for this is, that however unjust, or corrupt the persons of Parliament men in present or future may prove or whatever ill they may doe to particular parties (or to the whole in particular things) during their respective termes, or periods, yet they shall not have the temptation or advantage of an unlimited power fixed in them during their own pleasures, whereby to perpetuate injustice, and oppression upon any (without end and remedy) or to Advance and uphold, one particular party, Faction or intrests, whatsoever, to the oppression, or previdice of the community, and the enslaving the Kingdom to all posterity, but that the people may have an equal hope, or possibility, if they have made an ill choice at one time to mend it in another, and the members of the house themselves may be in acapacity to tast of subjection
as well as Rule, and may so be enclined, to consider of other mens cases, as what may come to be their own.

And doe declare that the Legislative power and the power of finall judgements, most unfit and dangerous (as to the peoples Intrest) to be fixd in the persons of any dureing life, or at their own pleasures, and wher ever it is, and continues so it renders that state noe better then a Tyran • y or the people subjected to it no better then vassal • s, &c.

div.head: Annot.
div.p: IF the opposing Arbitrary power, violence and oppression exercised by particular parties or intere • ts, & the asserting the peoples just power and rights in their Representors, assembled in the Supream authority, was that by which you would declare you were not a Mercenary Army hired to serve the arbitrary power of a state. How then can your selves or others, who with soberness weigh things, judge otherwise of you, who not onely ab • t, but with Swords by your sides uphold your Generall, who by deceit and violence hath rooted up these very foundations of Right and Freedome; advancing himself and interest upon their ruines. And if it were sound doctrine in that day for you to stand up, and plead against such Tyrany and Oppression, if exercised by them, who were a lawfull power; will it not then justifie those who have not Apostatized from but are more refined in those honest principles, that shall plead and rise up against the very same, and greater Oppression exercised by your Protector and his Councel, who are an unlawfull and usurping Power.

And if you might in that day honestly Vindicate and justifie your practise by the examples of the free people of other Nations, and plead the rationality and justnes of the Scots associating in Covenant for the redemption of their Liberties, entrench upon by their King without any visible forme of Authority to owne them therein, then for shame condemne your selves for what you have said already, be silent and open your mouthes no more for the fu • ure, against those who upon more refined principles having the glory of God, and good of the Nation singly in their eye, that are and shall be raised up by him, to stand up and plead for in Order thereto a performance of things according to the true intent of all those glorious words, conteynd in your severall Declarations Remonstrances and Engagements though they have no forme of an Authority to countenance or owne them for if it were lawfull then it is so now.

And if in the Parlaments Judgement and yours it were no resisting of Magistracy then to side with just principles, and that according to the Law of nature and Nations, the most Lawfull Authority might be opposed if intrenching upon the Nations rights and freedomes and doe plead the justnes of it from the practise of our Ancestors and the successe they had therein. Then by your own words they are excused from resisting of magistracy, who in this day are siding with, and pleading for the very same asserted Kights and freedoms now entrench upon by your Protector, who is no magistrate, but an usurper.

And douptles such may expect noe lesse a blessing from God in beareing their witnes against the justice, and unrighteousnes of them in power who have so far declined their former honest principles declared in their remonstrances Declarations and Engagements, &c. As thay have builded again, and do stand upon the very foundation, they had destroyed with so large, an expence of bloud, and treasure, and their practise therein is justified (if you should blame them) not only by the people of other Nation, but by yours also.

By these words it appeares that some in that day feared that you would impose such persons to rule over them as would cheifly be for the advance of your particular Intrest, and the suppressing whatever closed not with it, and to clear your selves from this, you declared that to do so were to entrench upon the peoples rights, &c. And that the only way to bring in equal righteousnes & justice, to all without respect to persons, & to keep out vassels to particular and private intrests, was that men who had not forfeited that Liberty might chuse their Rulers. But do you not after all these specious pretences to reason and justice, stand by and uphold a few of your own society, with others, who contrary to law and the consent of the people, have fixed this power, and way of Government
in the hands of your Generall and a Councell, (who are vassalls to his intrest) during life, to the inflaving of all others, who comply not with his and your private Intres • s, whereby that which they then feared is come upon them.

And if to put the government during life or pleasure into the hands of such persons as appeare most righteous and for common good may so endanger their being corrupt and settling into perties, as without dispute would end, in the support of their own intrests to the oppressing of others, and the onely way to hinder the perpetuating this slavery and oppression be that this power should be limited by certain periods put to their sitting and others to be chosen in their stead, which doubtlesse according to the honest spirit which acted then and the same spirit more refined, which is breathing now and right reason, is the only way to hinder ty • an • , slavery and bond age from comming upon the Nation then what bondage and slavery have you (after all these glorious words and profession brought upon the Saints and people of the Nation, either in your setting up or maintaining, now he is up a single person and his Councell with an unlimited power during life, with provision for a con • inuance thereof in these that shall succeed him, whereby (except the Lord prevent) we are irrecoverably brought under a perpetuall tyrany vassallage, and oppression againe which your selves confesse in the following words.

div.head: In a Representation of the desires of the Officers and Souldiers of a Regiment of horse quarterd in the County of Northumberland to the Lord Generall Fairefax.
div.p: They hold forth the first ground, and the of tyrany over the • ree borne people of this Nation to proceed from the Bastard of William the sixth Duke of Normandy, who to prevent the English of all recovery and relief by their parliaments in future, he created Lords by his Patent, and Prerogative, to si • by succession in Parliament, as Representors of his conquest and Tyrany over us, and not by Election of the People, as the Representors and Patrons of the Common-wealth.

And to add unto this, to make his U • u • pation firme and inviolable, he subdued the Law-giving Power of the free people of England in their Parliaments, to the Negative voice of himself and Posterity, &c. And under the yoak of this Norman captivity and villainage, we have been • eld by that succession, even to this day.

And this King, to uphold the constitution and settlement of those principles, and forms of tyranny, and in them his dominion
over us, brought a cruel and bloudy war upon this Nation, against whom with your Excellency, under authority of Parliament, we have freely engaged; to the end we might rescue the legislative Powers of our English Parliament, our free Customes, and native Rights, from the bondage of that Captivity, and so free our selves, and all the people, from the common Oppressions of the Land, by a settlement of a just and equall government of Right, and Freedome.

But instead of this, we finde the Parliament betake themselves to a complyance and Treaty, with our Conquered Enemy, courting his pleasure, and allowing him a Negative voice, in the passing all Acts of Parliament: Whereby our Indempnity, our Laws, and Liberties are all subjected to his Concession, his will, advanced above all laws, above the Parliament and people, and himself put out of the reach of Justice, and made accountable to none; unto which yoak of Norman Captivity (after all the bloud that hath been spilt against it) We are loath to be subjected again, as we see both we and all the people must needs be, except the Army interpose betwixt the people, and their destroyers, and make good their Engagement at New-market Heath, with all their Remonstrances, Declarations, and Promises to the people, &c. Upon which, they call upon the Generall, to put forth his power, for the relief
and release of this oppressed Nation; in order to which, they present their desires under 38. particular heads: But for brevitie sake, there are onely four of them mentioned in this place, viz. 2. 20. 22. 28. &c.
2. That the exaction of Tythes and all manner of Impropriations be removed; and that the publick Ministry be otherwise provided for.
20. That our Parliament for the future be secured, and cleared from the Negative voice of any single person, or persons whatsoever.
22. That a • l Statutes, Laws, and Acts of Parliament, be made and run onely in the name of the Commons of England assembled in Parliament.
28. That no man be kept in Prison above a moneth, but in that space to be brought to a Tryall by a lawfull Jury of his equals, or else to be discharged of course.

For these things we declare, and with our swords in our hands, as we are Souldiers, we challenge them as the price and purchase of our bloud, to live and dye for them, against all Opposers whatsoever.
And as we are English men we claim them as our own inheritance, and birth-right; and do beg the Generall to give them assistance and encouragement, for the accomplishment of these things, that themselves, the people and Generations to come, may have just cause to blesse God for his righteous conduct, &c.

div.head: Ano • .
div.p: And will it not be the same if your Protector by his power and force bring in his Bashaws, or Maj. Generals, chosen neither by God nor his people, to sit as Lords for the support of his Inter • st, and that over a Parliament (so called) not of the peoples, but his own chusing, is not this greater tyranny then that so much complained of, which the Basturd exercised in that day.

And hath not your Protector done the same, for by his negative voice, or rather his power in the Militia, he will let no law passe though never so much for Publique welfare if it entrench upon his Ʋsurpation, and if the peoples Representors do not gratify his lusts therein he presently dissolves them, wherefore are we not under the Norman Yoak now as we • l as formerly?

And doth not your Protectors saying, he will lay down his old bones in maintaining his usurpt Power, declare, that another blouldy war will unavoydably
come upon the Nation? For can it be imagined, that after the expense of of much bloud and treasure, also the faith, prayers, and appeales of the Saints put up, and your Declarations, Remonstrances and Engagements, for our just Rights and Freedomes, and against these principles and formes of Tyranny, that the Lord will suffer us to be of so base and low a spirit, as to bow our Necks to the very same Yoaks of Tyrany again.

And have not some persons in the Army and elsewhere, who being adulterated from their virgin spirit and principles, and looking at the favour and fear of man more than at the Lord, who have lately complyed with your Protectors interest, to the hatching and bringing forth a Paper, called the Instrument of Government: Whereby is given him a Negative voice, so much opposed and denyed to the late King. Whereby our persons, laws, libe • ies, and the supreme Authority of the Nation, are subjected to his lust, and he exempted from the reach of Justice, and being so, why may we not complain, and declare against these things, and be as unwilling to submit thereto, as you to the very same in the King: and incase you uphold him in the violation of all these wholesome words, and declarations, as justly endeavour to free our selves and Countrey from our present Oppression, as you might have done in that day.

Contrary to this not onely Tythes, but the law to compel those to pay treble damages, who refused to pay them is established also notwithstanding your Protector said to Mr. Jessy and others, they should call him Jugler, if they were not taken away by 3. September 1654.

But by the Instrument of Government your Protector hath his Negative voice in all things that oppose his Government, and such power in you the Militia and Navy, that nothing shall be done that doth not like him.

Through the Apostacy of this day they do now run in the name of a Protector, as formerly in the name of the King, contrary to the former and present desires of the Lords people, who then did, and now do, keep close to these honest Principles.

Why then are the true Patriots and Assertors of Right and Freedome kept in Prison, for above a year together, without any thing laid to their charge, seeing the face of an accuser, or being brought to a legal Tryall: Nay, some of them, their friends, scarce suffered to come and see them, and upon no other account, but because they presse to have these good things done, according to the very spirits of our desires in these Declarations, &c.

What is become of this honest Heroick couragious spirit, for Righteousnesse, and breaking the Yoaks of Oppression, in which the Lord so owned you? Hath the Kings houses, Parks, and the great things of this world stopt your eares, and blinded
your eyes, that you cannot, or rather will not hear the cry of your brethrens bloud, nor the many declarations, remonstrances, &c. for the bringing forth those good things you seem so much to plead for, Are not the freedoms and liberties of the people, as well worth the contending for as ever. Why do you not now with swords in your hands challenge these liberties, to live and dye for them against your Protector, the onely Grand Opposer of them, and beg your Collonells, &c. with the faithfull Patri • ts & people of the Nation, to give you enragement and assistance for the accomplishment of these things, that so the Gener • tions to come, may have just cause to blesse God for you.

div.head:
In a Letter to the Generall from divers Officers of the Army in the North, concerning the late large Petition presented to the Parlia
•• nt, 11. Sept. 1648. aforementioned.
div.p:
Seeing that we and all the well affected of the Land, ventured our lives and all that was • ear unto us, not sparing cheerfully and faithfully, to passe through all dangers and difficulties with you, attending that Engagement. We are embold • ned now at last (having looked round about us, and finding neither your Excellency, the Army, nor people yet answer a to those ends, to make our humble ad
• resse to your Excellency in this juncture of time, wherein we apprehend, that t • e b • ou • that hath been spilt, the Conquests that God hath crowned us withall, the treasure and wealth of the people expended, is all upon the point being rendred in vain, and of none effect. For to the sorrow of our hearts, we finde that even those particulars of common Right and Freedom, for which we took up armes and stil • continue them, are not regarded, though by way of humble Peti
•• on, • o • ely presented to the House of Commons, by the well affected in and about London; and instead of answering their just desires of freedome, and safety to the people, we finde a Treaty with 〈◊〉 c • nquered Enemy is now chosen and • igorously carried on &c.

We having seriously weighed the foresaid Petition Intituled, The humble •• tition of thousa • ds well affected persons, inhabiting the City of London, Westminster, the Borough of Southwark, Hamblets, and places adjacent; presented to the Parliament 11. September 1648. As also our dear Friends from the Garrisons of Newcastle and Tinmouth, and finding the
common safety of us all wrapt up in these desires, we cannot in duty to God, to our own Native Countrey, and in Honour to your Excellencies safety, and all that have adheared to you, but resent the said desires as our own, and humbly implore, That your Excellency will be pleased so to appear before us in the cause of the people, &c. That we and all the people with the Generations after us, by your Excellencies happy conduct, may have just cause to blesse God on your behalf, &c.

div.head: Several of the chief passages contained in the large Petition, presented by thousands well affected persons inhabiting the City of London, Westminster, Southwark, the Hamlets, &c. mentioned in the foregoing Letter.
div.p: Be pleased to understand that we had not engaged on your part, but that we judged this honourable House to be the supreme Authority of England, as chosen by and representing the people, and entrusted with absolute power for redresse of grievances, and provision for safety, and that the K. was but at the most, the chief publick Officer of this Kingdom, and accountable to this House (the Representative of the people) from whom all just Authority is or ought to be derived for discharge of his Office: And if we had not been confident hereof, we had been desperately mad to have taken up Armes, or to have been ayding and assisting in maintaining a War against him, the Laws of the Land making it expresly a Crime no lesse than Treason, for any to raise war against the King.

But when we considered the manifold Oppressions brought upon the Nation by the King, &c. and that it was evident that the King intended to raise forces and to make War, and that if he did set up his Standard, it tended to the dissolution of the Government: Upon this knowing the safety of the people to be above Law, and that to judge thereof appertained to the supeam Authority, and not to the supream Magistrate; and being satisfied in our consciences, that the publik safety and freedome was in eminent danger, we concluded we had not onely just cause to maintain, but the supream Authority of the Nation to justifie, defend, and indempnifie us in time to come, in what we should performe by direction thereof, though against the known Law of the Land, or any inferiour Authority though the highest. And as our understanding was begot in us by principles of Right Reason, so were we cōfirmed therin by your own proceedings, as by your condemning those Judges who in the case of ship-money had declared the K. to be Judge of
safety, and by your denying him a negative voyce in the making of Laws; where you wholly exclude the King from having any share in the supream Authority: Then by your casting the Bishops out of the house of Lords, who by Tradition also had been accounted, an essential part of the supream Authority. And by your declaring to the Lords, that if they would not joyn with you in settling the Militia, you would settle it without them, which you could not justly have done, had they had any reall share in the supream Authority.

These things we took for reall demonstrations, that you undoubtedly knew your selves to be the supream Authority, ever weighing down in us all other your indulgent expressions, concerning the King or Lords, it being for us impossible to believe, that it can consist either with the safety or freedome of the Nation, either to be governed by three or two supreams, especially where experience hath approved them so apart to differ in their judgments concerning freedome, or safety, that the one hath bin know to punish, what the other hath judged worthy of reward, when not onely the freedome of the people is directly opposite to the prerogative of Kings, &c.

And whenas most of the oppressions of the Common-wealth, have in all times been brought upon the people by the King and Lords, who neverthelesse would be so equall in the supream Authority, as that there should be no redresse of grievances, no provision for safety, but at their pleasure, For our parts we professe our selves to be so far from judging this to be consistant with freedome, or safety, that we know not greater wherfore we assisted you in the late wars, but in hope to be delivered by you, from so intolerable, so destructive a bondage, so soon as you should (through Gods blessing upon the Armies raised by you) be enabled.

But to our exceeding grief we have observed, that no sooner God vouchsafeth you victory, and blesseth you with successe, and thereby enableth you to put us and the whole Nation, in an absolute constitution of freedome and safety, but according as ye have been accustomed, passing by the ruine of the Nation, and all the bloud that hath been spilt by the King and his party, ye betake your selves to a Treaty with him, thereby putting him that is but one single person, and a publick Officer of the Common-wealth, in competition with the whole body of the people whom ye represent, not considering that it is impossible for you to erect any Authority equall to your selves and declared to all the world, that you will not alter the Ancient Government from that of Kings, Lords, and Commons: Not once mentioning, in case of difference
which of them is supream, but leaving that point (which was the chifest cause of all our publick differences, wars, and miseries) as uncertain as ever.

In so much that we who upon these grounds have laid out our selves to the utmost of our abillities, and all throughout the land both Souldiers and others, who have done the like in defence of your supream Authority, and in opposition to the King, cannot but deem our selves in the most dangerous condition of all others, left without all plea of indempnity for what we have done, &c. Nor can we possibly conceive how any that have assisted you, can be any way exempted from the guilt of Murderers and Robbers, by the present Laws in force, if you persist to disclaim the supream Authority, though their own consciences acquit them, as having opposed none but manifest Tyrants, Oppressors, and their adherents, &c. Here followeth some particulars mentioned in the Petition, others being omitted for brevity sake.
The truth is we have long expected things of another Nature from you, and such as we are confident would have given satisfaction to all serious people of all parties, As,
First, that you would have made good the supream Authori • y of the people in this honourable House from all pretences of Negative voices, either in King or Lords.
Secondly, that you would have made Laws for election of Representatives, yearly, and of course, without Writ or Summons.

Thirdly, that you would have set expresse tearms for their meeting, continuance, and dissolution, as not to exceed fourty or fifty dayes at the most, and to have fixed an expresse time for the ending of this present Parliament.

Fourthly, that you would have exempted matters of Religion and Gods Worship, from the compulsive or restrictive power of any Authority upon earth, and reserved to the supream Authority an uncompulsive power onely of appointing a way for the publick, whereby abundance of misery, persecutions, and heart burnings, would for ever be avoided.

Eightly, that you would have freed all men from being examined against themselves, and from being questioned or punished for doing that, a
• ainst which no law hath been provided.
Sixteenthly, that you would have removed the tedious burden of Tythes, satisfying all Impropriators, and providing a more equal way of maintenance for the Publick Ministers.

The things and worthy Acts that have been done, and achieved by this Army and their adherents (however ing • atfully suffered to be scandallized, as Secta • ies and men of corrupt judgments) in defence of the just Authority of this honourable House, and of the common Liberties of the Nation, and in opposition to all kind of Tyrany and Oppression, being so far from merriting in odious Act of Oblivion, that they rather deserve a most honourable Act of perpetual Remembrance, to be as a patterne of publick vertue, fidelity, and resolution to all posterity.

div.head: A Gratulatory Letter from divers Officers of the Army at the League before Ba • wick, to the late Presentors of the large Petition of Sept. 11. 1648.

body.p:
As we all languish and groan under the insupportable weight of the pubick oppression of the land, so it is our duty to strugle and strive joyntly together, for the relief of each other, for to our Neighbour we are bound as to our selves, and we are all the sonnes of one Nation, and Brethren by nature, whose several weale and woe, is included and wrapt up in the fold of one common-wealth, that we must even stand and fall together. We (though we have our swords in our hands) cannot be without you, nor you without us, in this day of publick calamity; and of this (we do not question but) as we with you, so you with us, are sufficiently sensible, which to all consciencious and juditious men, may be sufficient to tye us firmly together in one common bond of unity, against all our Oppressors and Opposers of freedome whatsoever
But in this we give you the preheminence, for though we are with you in heart and affection, for the principles of cōmon right & freedome to the Land; yet we must give you the right hand of fellowship, in appearing and going before us therein; for the great refreshment of our spirits, we finde that God hath preserved yet thousands for us, that have not bowed their knee to Baal, and are yet (after all these afflictions and tryals) firme and untainted with the poisonous principles of Oppress • on and Tyranny, as by your two late Pet • ions appeareth; for which we are bound in duty to render the glory thereof unto God, so in all • umane and civil obligation, we cannot but render our gratefull and cordial respects unto you for the same, and must professe it our duty to attest the same wi •• our sword • , in, and for those just principles (in your Petit • on cont • ined) to live and die with you and for you.

closer.dateline: From the Leagure before Barwick Sept. 30. 1648.

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
Have you by writing and printing incouraged & invited the faithfull in the land, to stand by and own you with their p • rsons, purses, & prayers, pretending to be one with them in pressing for, and endeavouring after their Rights, and Freedomes, in the way of a Common-wealth, opposed to the interest of a Monarch or single person, commending their forwardnesse theirin, blessing the Lord he had kept them from bowing their knee to Baal, viz. the principles of Tyranny and Oppression, as if you abhorred i • , and did never intend so much as to think of entering into, or to be upholding of the practise of such principles your selves. And do you after your own turn are served, deceive them in the setting up or in maintaining when up, the very same Interests, Tyranny, and Oppression, of a single person in your Protector. Thou that sayest, another should not bow to Baal, and doest so thy self, thy condemnation is jus • ; these things considered, you are concerned to look about
you, and as you were then ready with swords in your hands, to stand by the faithfull of the land, in and for those just principles contained in their Petition, and to live and dye for them, in opposition to the King. So it behoves you to be as ready to do the same against your Protector, who more opposes these good things now, than the King did then, lest that this bloud of your friends which hath been shed upon, and after those incouraging words, be fruitlesse and in vain, and the guilt thereof be charged upon you.

div.head: In an other Declaration of the Generall and Council of warr, they say as followes:
div.p:
And if when this Kingdome hath spent so much of its bloud and treasure, hath past through such un
• eard of dangers, & overcome such difficulties so many years toget • er, all that they must now h • pe for, and rest in, must onely be what •••• ing gran •• in his Message of the • 2. of May last, and if this •• st be i • pos •• up • n mens judgments and consciences by an Oath, and 〈◊〉 entered into in a tumultuous and unlawfull way, and by out • age
maintained in despight and contempt of the Parliament: If, rather than this should not be accomplish- the Parliament must be violated and forced into the hands of such of the Members thereof, a • have secretly abetted and fomented those practises to that end, that these hidden councels and works of darknes, might when they come to their full birth, have the Image of highest Authority in the face of them, the better to gain credit thereunto, and secure the Authors, of them from punishment. If these tings we say must be the end and upshot of all, what then remains to this poor Kingdome and all true hearted Englishmen, but to joyn together as one man, with their counsells, estates, and lives, in this way as our last refuge under God, which he by his wise and gracious providence hath reserved and provided, by keeping up this Army, even to a Myracle, so to prevent the aforesaid evils, and to procure to this dying Kingdome, yet a settled peace and happinesse.

These things being seriously considered by us, we have thought fit in the name of the Army, to declare that all such Members of either house of Parliament, as are already with the Army, for the security of their persons, and for the ends aforesaid, are forced to absent themselves from Westminster. That we all hold and esteem them as persons in whom the
publick trust of the Kingdome is still remaining, though they cannot for the present sit as a Parliament with freedome and safety at Westminster; and by whose advice and counsel, we desire to govern our selves in, in the managing these weighty affaires, and to that end we invite them to make repair to the Army, to joyn with us in this great cause, we b • ing resolved, and do hereby faithfully oblige our selves to stand by them therein, and to live and dye with them against all opposition whatsoever, &c.

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
And may not we take up the same complaint, and say; And if when this Nation hath spent so much bloud and Treasure, and overcome such difficulties for so many yeares together, First, against the Tyranny of the King and together therewith, the Acts and Engagements of Parliament, and your Declarations against Mona • chy it self, and for a Common-wealth, a • d would have no Ki • g •• t J • s •• ; and yet after all this for your Generall, out of his desire of domin • tion to as •• m • to himself, and
impose upon us the very same forme of Government and more Tyrannicall and Arbitrary than the former, and rather than this shall not be accomplished, first, the old Parliament must be broken, upon pretence they would do no good but perpetuate themselves, and when the little Parliament was chosen, and were doing these good things the others were turned out for not doing, a party of them for his interest, must early in the morning before the others could get together, without putting it to a Vote, in a cheating manner, go away with their pretended power to him, and the others who stayed behinde, turned out in a violent manner, by some of you (as Reforma- does and Prentices by the instigation of those corrupt Members you here complain of, made those of the Parliament, who would not joyn with them, fly to the Army for shelter) That so these hidden counsels and works of darknesse, might have the Image of the highest Authority upon the face of them, the better to gain credit thereunto. If these things we say must be the end and upshot of all (which is worse than what the King stood upon in his Message of the 12. of May, what then remains to all true hearted Englishmen, but (according to your advice in the like case) to joyn together as one man with their councels, estates, and lives, in this way as our last refuge under God, to hinder the progresse of the aforesaid Tiranny, and to procure to this Nation its just and lawfull Rights, and Freedomes, and in order thereunto, to call unto their assistance such persons, who were turned out of the little Parliament,
and have not since defiled their garments, and such of the old Parliament with others, whose hearts are faithfull withall, who fear the Lord, t • ue friends to justice and liberty, and haters of tyranny, and to esteem them as persons in whom the publick trust of the Nation is still of right remaining and to be governed by their advice and counsell, in managing the weighty affairs, and resolve to stand by them therein, and to live and dye with them against all opposition whatsoever. Surely this may as honestly be done against your Generalls upstart Government, as for you to have done the same against the King, and that corrupt party in the Parliament whom you so opposed in that day.

div.head: In the case of the Army stated and proposed by the agents of five Regiments of horse (viz. Lievtenant Generalls, Commissary Generalls, Collonel Fleetwoods Collonell Riches, Collonell Whaleys,) to their respective Regiments and the whole Army, and presented to the Generall Sr. Thomas Fairfax Oct. 15. 1647.
div.p: Page 4. say they, It is declared in the Armies Declaration 14. June 1647. that the Army took up armes in judgement and conscience for the peoples just rights and liberties, and not as Mercinary souldiers hired to serve the Arbitrary power of the State and that in the same manner it continu • d in arm • s at that time.

And in Page 7. of ihe same declaration, it was declared, they proceeded upon the principles of right and Freedome, and upon the
law of nature and Nations. But the strength of the endeavours of many hath been and are now spent to perswade the souldiers and agitators, that they stand as souldiers onely to serve the State, and may not as free commoners, claim their freedome as due to them, as those ends for which they have hazzarded thir lives, &c.

Page 6. In Declaration 14. June Page 10. as in all other Remonstrances and declarations it was desired that the rights and liberties of the people might be secured, before the Kings businesse should be considered. But now the grievances of the people are propounded to be considered after the restoring him to the Regal Power, and that in such a way according to the proposals, viz. with a Negative voice, that the people that have purchased by bloud what was their right, of which the King endeavoured to deprive them, should yet solely depend on his will for relief in their grievances and Oppressions, &c.
It hath been alwaies profest and declared that the Army was called forth, and conjured by the Parliaments Declarations for defence of the peoples just rights, against the forces raised by the King.

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
When that corrupt party both in Parliament and Army told you, you onely served the State for wages, & might not as free commoners claim your freedomes as your due upon hazzard of your lives: You then could quote severall declarations to manife t you engaged not as Mercinary Souldiers, but for the peoples rights, yet now notwithstanding, your G • nerall deprives us of the same rigbts which they endeavoured to do, and hath his negative voice and all things concerning the r • lief of the peoples grievances more under his own dispose
than ever the King had, and you can be silent as if that honest spirit you seem here to be acted by were dead or was never truly breathing in you.

Whereas it is now many months since the Army declared, that they would insist upon the peoples interest as in Declaration 14. June P. 13. and yet no relief for the people in any of their Oppressions by Arbitrary powers, Monopolies, injustice in the proceeding at Law. Tythes, &c. is effectually procured nor any greater probability of future help is visible than was before, no foundations of freedom being yet l • id, and yet the souldery burthens the countrey, and occasions great taxes, upon which these five mischiefs follow.
I shalll onely mention some of them.

1. The love and affecton of the people to the Army is decayed,
cooled, and near lost; its already the common voice of the people, what good hath our new saviours done for us? what grievance have they procured to be redressed? wherein is our condition bettr • d, or how are we more free than before, &c?

3. Whiles the peoples old Oppressions are continued, and more Taxes are imposed for pay of the Army, they are disabled daily more & more for the maintenance of an Army for their preservation, for they begin to say, they can but be destroyed by Oppress • on, and its all one to them, whether it be by pretended friends or professed enemies, it were a • good say they, that the King should rule again by prerogative, we were slaves then to his will, and we are now no better, we had rather have one Tyrant than hundreds.

4. Page 9. By this means the people are inclined to tumults, crying out, will none procure relief for us? Shall we alwaies be deluded with fair words, and be devoured by professors? we must 'ere long rise up in armes, and every one catch what he can, thus confusion is threatened.

5. Many Souldiers are asham • d of themselves and fear that the people should rise to destroy them; you will do nothing for us (say they) we are vexed by Malignant Judges for conscience sake, by arbitrary Committees in the countrey, and at Parliament Ordering one thing to day, and recalling it the next; injustice in the Law is the same, and we buy our right at as dear a rate as ever, Tythes are inforced from us double and treble, &c.

Page 10 They thought (viz the old Parliament) we would have stood as Mercenary Souldiers hired to serve their Arbitrary Power, and not remembred that we by their invitation took up armes in judgement
and conscience, to preserve the Nation from Tyranny and Oppression, and therefore were obliged to insist upon our rights and freedoms, as Commoners, &c. and upon this ground we judge the Parliament hath proceeded of late, to encrease the peoples Oppressions, by an Ordinance for treble damages to be paid by all that refuse (though for conscience sake) to pay Tythes, and an Ordinanc to look up the Printing Presses against whom they please, w • ich was in the Bishops time complained of as one of the great Oppressions, &c.

And may not we say, its some years past, since you declared you would not disband till you saw the foundations of the peoples freedomes and liberties surely laid, and yet we are further off than when you sp • ke these words, for thorough the Oppression and Tyranny of your Generall, &c. Monopolies, as formerly are encouraged, not onely in Merchandize and other things, but upon the Scriptures also, insomuch that a Bible is not now to be had unlesse we pay ten pence more than formerly they were sold for, And this your Master doth to encourage his Printers to turn Cachpoles and to be the more diligent in the suppressing of that truth (chiefly) which discovers his Hypocricy, neither can any man • x • ept he own his usurpt power, have benefit of the law, and is
so tyrannicall, that no Lawyer dare▪ plead in a cause again • t him though never so just, as our experience can witnesse. These things considered with his imprisoning the Saints for non payment of Tythes, and their not complying with him, but opposing his declention from those honest principles you here so much declare for, with many other grievances now lying upon us and likely to be continued by your closing with him, and yet notwithstanding, great Taxes continued for your pay, No wonder if you have lost the peoples love, and they as formerly do ask, where is the good the Army hath done us after their large professions which is now no more than in change of the person, and in taking off Charls his yoa • , to keep on Olivers; Now if upon their • eing thus deluded, they contrive how to deliver themselves, and Tumults do rise upon this account, then consider whether by these words, you do not acknowledge, that Oppressors and Tyran • s are the causers of it.
Anot.

p.hi: And is not this Ordinance for treble damages renued by your General and such who for conscience sak • refuse to pay Tythes more violently persecuted than ever, to the imprisonment of some, and undoing of others, as ulso the Printing Presses upon all occasions diligently searcht, and a strict charge laid upon the Printers, least any thing come fo • th to manifest the back-sliding of this day; I forbare • o name the Over-seers of this work, or where they are related, least the true s • ed among them suffer for their sakes; but when such persons come to do the devils work, for the riches and • onour of this world, its high time to searce Jerusalem with candles, they are as evident suppressors of truth, as ever the Bishops and their pandors were in that day, which will be proved to their faces if they dare stand the tryall.

div.p: Page 13. Through the Armies declining its first principles to insist upon satisfaction and security as Souldiers and Commoners before disbanding, or deviding, the Army is now likely to be so farr scattered into several quarters, that it shall be in no capacity to insist upon security for arrears, sufficient indempni • y, or any of its own or the Nations rights, in case they shall be still denyed them.

Page 13. Its to be considered that the enemies on the one hand, and the other encrease daily in their confidence and strength, whilest security for the Armies arrears and constant future pay are not provided, and the rights and freedomes of the people are not cleared and secured, and the Army
may devide in case one part should insist upon the first just principles, and be faithfull thereunto, and another part should by flatteries, preferments, fear, or negligence, decline or desert them, and let it be considered how far this will endanger the ruine of the Army and Kingdome.

We never did nor do regard the worst of evils or mischiefs that can befall o • r selves, in comparison of the consequence of them to the poor Nation, or to the security of common right and freedome, we could not but in reall, not formall trouble of heart for the poor Nation and oppressed people, break forth and cry, O our bowels! our bowells! we are troubled at the very heart, to hear the peoples dolefull groans, and yet their expected deliverers will not hear, or consider; they have run too and fro, and sighed or even wept forth their sorrowes and miseries in Petition first to King, then to Parliament, and then to Army; yet they all have been like broken reeds, even the Army it self on whom they leaned, have peirced their hands, their eyes, even failed with looking for peace and freedome, but behold nothing but Oppression, distraction and trouble, &c We wish therefore the bowells of compassion, of the whole Army, might yearn towards their distressed Brethren, and that they might with one consent say each to other, Come let us joyn together speedily, to demand present redresse for the peoples grievances, and security for all their and our rights and freedomes, as souldiers and commoners, let us never devide each from other, till those just demands
be answered really and effectually, that so for the peoples ease, as many forces as are not absolutely necessary, may be speedily disbanded, and our honour may be preserved unspoted, when they shall see that we minded not our own interest, but the good fr • dome and wellfare of the w • ol • Nation.

It seems that corrupt party beforementioned in Parliament and Army, did designe and endeavour to quarter the Army at such a distance from one another, that wh • n they come to disband, you might not be in a capacity to insist upon those good things, for which you took up armes at fir • t, the consideration whereof▪ and the appearance of ruin which was like to come upon the Nation, if this design had taken, did seemingly so affect your hearts, that you could not bear it, but cryed out, O your B • w lls! your Bowells! and profest to be so carefull of the peoples rights, as if you mind • d their security more than your own, and complain, that the King and Pa • liament had failed them like broken re • ds, yea the Army it s • lf, on whom they had leaned, had peirced th • ir hands, but your selves to be such
friends as would never leave them till their rights and liberties were secured, by which good words and fair speeches they were drawn away to be so simple, and sinfull as to leane upon you, who like broken reeds have peirced their hands as well as they you so complain of; for instead of taking away their oppressions and providing for their liberties, you keep on the one, and obstruct the other. And therefore if you would approve your selves to the Lord and his people, that you have minded his glory and their good more than your own, and would engage their hearts again unto you, then bring forth fruit worthy of repentance, and say in heart as well as words, Come Brethren and fellow Commoners, the truth is, you have leaned too much upon us, and therefore it is just with the Lord, for this sinne of yours, and our too much minding our arrears and futu • e pay, the favour of men and our worldly concernments, that we have so deceived you hitherto, but seeing our evil, we are resolved in the the streng • h of the Lord, if you will joyn with us, we will never devide any more from you, till this beastly foundation with its tyranny, be thrown down, and those good things brought forth, we have formerly so declar • d for, for we plainly see we shall never be right till we come to this.
Now to all that shall thus appear we propound,

Page 14. That whatsoever was porposed to be insisted upon either in Declaration of June 14. or the Remonstrance of June 23. and in the Remonstrance from Kingston August 18. be adheared to resolvedly, so as not to recede from those desires, untill they be throughly and effectually answered: More particularly that whereas it appears by positive Laws, and ancient just customes, that the people have • right to new successive elections for Parliaments, at certain periods of time, and that it ought not to be denyed them, being so essentiall to their freedome, that without it they are no better than slaves, the nature of that legislative power being arbitrary, and that therefore it be insisted on so possitively and resolvedly, as not to recede from it.

Page 15. Whereas Parliaments rightly constituted, are the foundation of our hopes of right and freedome to this people, and whereas the people have been prevented of Parliaments, though many positive laws have been made for a constant succession of Parliaments, that therfore it be possitively and resolvedly infisted upon, that a law paramount be made, enacting it to be unalterable by Parliaments, that the people shall of course meet without any Writ or Warrants, once in every two years, on an appointed day in their respective Counties, for the electiton of their Representors in Parliament, &c.

div.head: Annot.
div.p: Although this case of the Army stated, with some Letters and other things contained in this collection, do come onely in the names of some particular Troops, or Regiments, yet the Agent were encouraged therein by your Generall, who was then Lievtenant Generall, and some other Officers of the Army, wh • (in tha • day) more eminently appeared for righteousnesse, and the honest Sectarian part of the pepople of God, than others, and have nothing in them, but what doth center in, and agree with, the Remonstrance at Albon • , the agreement with the people, and with the tree Acts of Parliament comming after, which the Army approved of, and consented to, and what might be spoken as to Parliaments in this place, I referr you to them.

Wereas all power is originally and essentially in the whole body of the people of this Nation, and whereas their free choise or consent by their Representors, is the onely originall or foundation of all just government; and the reason and end of the choise of all just Governors whatsoever, is their apprehension of safety and good by them, that it be insisted upon positively, that the supream power of the peoples Representors or Commons ass • mbled in Parliament, be forthwith clearly declared as their power to make Laws, or repeal Laws, &c. as also their power to call to an account all Officers of this Nation whatsoever, for their neglects, or their treacheries in their trust for the peoples good, and to continue or remove them from their Offices according to their demerrits, &c. And further, that this power constitute any kinde of Governors or Officers, that they shall judge for the peoples good, &c. This power of Commons in Parliament, is the thing against which the King hath contended, and the people have defended with their lives, and therefore ought now to be demanded as the price of their bloud.

They say the Generals answer was, that he judged their intentions were honest, and desired that every one of a publick spirit would be acting for the publick, and that for his part he had freely ventured his life for common right and freedome, and should freely engage it again; adding further, that he thought it meet it should be presented to the Generall Councill.

div.head:
In the Remonstance of the Army at Albons 16 ••
• e 1648. presented to the Commons assembled in Parliament the 20. following.
div.p: The summe of the publick interest of a Nation in relation to common right and freedome (which hath been the chief subject of our contest) and in opposition to tyranny and injustice to Kings, or others, we take to lye in these things following,

1. That for all matters of supream trust or concernment to the safety and welfare to rhe whole, they have a Commons and supream Councell or Parliament, and that (as to the common behalf, who cannot all meet together themselves) to consist of Deputies or Representors freely chosen by them, with as much equallity as may be, and those electi • ons to be successive and renewed, &c.

p.hi:
If the only probable way for the preservation of common right and freedome
in opposition to the tyranny and injustice of Kings or others be, that all matter, of supream Tru • t and Concernment for publique welfare should be in the hands of the peoples Deputies or Representors, freely, and successively chosen. Then surely your contest with the King, and shedding so much bloud, hath either been upon wrong and mistaken grounds, or else you are become most fearful Apostates, in forsaking this probable way, and upholding this power in the hands of your Generall as a single person and his Councell, as it was before in the King.

div.p: 2. That the power of making Laws Constitutions and Offices (for the preservation and concernment of the whole) and of altering or repealing and a bolishing the same (for removal of any publick grievance therein) and the power of finall judgement concerning war or peace, the safety and welfare of the people, and all civil things wh • tsoever, without further appeals to any created standing power, and the supream Trust in relation to all such things, may rest in that supream Counsell so as,

div.head: Annot.
div.p: Contrary to the grave intent and spirit of this particular, this power doth now recide in a Protector, and a Parliament, as it did formerly in a King and Parliament as appears Instr. Gov. Article 1. which power your Generall hath assumed to himself, purely for support of his Interest, and to keep the power in his own hand, which he could not well do, without li • king up the old vomit, and treading in the formerly •• rown-up paths of tyranny and oppression, he and you had been so instru •••• all to destroy.

1. That the ordinary ordering & government of the people may be by such Offices, and Administrations, and according to such Laws, and Rules, as by that Council or the Representative body of the people therein have been prescribed or allowed, and not otherwise.

2. That none of those extraordinary or arbitrary powers aforementioned, may be exercised towards the people by any as of right, but by that supream Council or by the Representative body of the people therein, nor without their advice or consent, may any thing be imposed upon or taken from the people, or if it be otherwise attemped that the people are not bound thereby, but free, and the attempter punishable.

3. That those extraordinary powers or any of them, may be exercised by that supream Councill, or by the Representative body of the people therein, and where they shall see cause to assume and exercise the same, in a matter which they finde necessary for the safety or well-being
of the people, their proceedings and determinations therein may be binding and conclusive to the people, and to all Officers of Justice, and Ministers of State whatsoever: And that it may not be left in the will of the King, or any particular persons (standing in their own interest) to oppose, make voide, or render ineffectuall, such their determinations, or proceedings, &c.

div.head: Annot.
div.p: Contrary to the intent and purport of these three particulars, hath your Generall rased down these foundations of right and freedome, usurping this power into his own hand, as chief Magistrate and his Councill, as appears Iust. Gov. Articles 2. 3. And if your will say it is in a Parliament too, its answered they bear but the name without the power, for at his lust and pleasure, if they own not his Government they are shut cut; and if they do own it, and do not Act according to his will and interest, they are dissolved. And you Souldiers, that force the people to pay Taxes, and uphold your Master whilest he arbitrarily and of his own head, layes impositions upon the estates of your friends, decimates the revenues of others without, or contrary to any Law establisht by the peoples Representors, according to your own words are worthy of punishment, and the people not obliged to such impositions, but may freely resist.

Page 16. These things contain the summe or main of publick interest, and as they are the ordinary subject of civil contests, in all mixt States, where they happen be • wixt the people and those who have assumed or claimed a standing priviledge or prerogative over them; so they have been in this of ours. And against these maters of publick intrest, this King hath all along (his reign) opposed, and given himself up to uphold and advance the interest of his and his Posterities will and power; First that there might be no such common Councill (no Parliaments) at all to restrain or check him, but that all these matters of supream Trust, concerning safety and all things else, might rest
rest in him and in his brest alone, without limit from, or acccount to any in earth.

Page 17. To support himself in that state or height of tyranny, and make it absolute, he raised his first and second armes against his people in both Kingdomes, when he found he could not keep up to that height to have all those extraordinary powers, and matters of trust in himself alone, then he fell to play lower, that at least none of them might be exercised by any without him, no not by all the Trustees of the land, nor in any case, tho never so necessary for the relief or saving of the people, &c. And for this when the Parliament did otherwise assume, in point of immediate safety, & punishment of Delinquents without him) he raised his third armes, &c. And though he raised with the pretense onely of opposing the execise of those extraordinary and arbitrary powers, by your selves or any other without him (which would not be allowed himself to exercise alone, yet in the raising and having raised that force, he did by it assume and exercise all kinds of absolute and arbitrary powers at his own will alone without Parliament, &c. But when (his other claims so far falling) it came to this, he that before would not have allowed the the Parliament or Kingdome • power for safety, but at his will, would (at least) make you know,
that not you, nor the Kingdome, should have any peace or quiet without him, and that neither Parliament nor any power on earth (whatsoever ills he had done, might for it attach, or meddle with his facred person, and for this last part of his Interest his fourth Armes was raised 1648. the Scotch invasion was procured, &c.

Page 21. That where a person trusted with a limited power to Rule according to Laws, and by his trust (with expresse Covenant and Oath also) obliged to preserve and protect the Rights and Liberties of the people, for, and by whom he is entrusted, shall not onely pervert that Trust, and abuse that power, to the hurt and prejudice of the generallity, and to the oppression (if not destruction of many of them, but also by the advantage of the trust and power he hath) shall rise to the ass • ming of hurtfull powers never committed to him? and indeed to take away all those foundations of Right and Liberties, and of redresse and remedy too, which the people had reserved from him, and to swallow up all into his absolute will and power, to impose or take away, yea, to d • stroy at his pleasure, and declining all appeale herein, to the established equall judgement (agreed upon as it were betwixt him and his people, in all immergent matters of difference betwixt them) or to any judgment of men at all, shall flye to the way of force upon his trusting people, and attempt by it to uphold and establish himself in that absolute tyrannicall power so assumed over
them and in the exercise thereof at pleasure, such a person in so doing, doth forfeit all that trust and power he had, and (absolving the people from the bonds of Covenant & peace betwixt him & them) does set them free to take their best advantage, and (if he fall wirhin their power) to proceed in judgement against him even for that alone if there were no more, and to make this good they quote Rom. 13.3. where they say Paul speaks of Magistracy in its constitution (not of a person abusively exercising it) to be Gods instrument for good to every one, therefore the Kings of the Israelites must know the Law for a rule Deut. 17. 2 King. 11.12. David in 2 Sam. 23. avoucheth a rule for all Rulers, he that ruleth among men, must be just, ruling in the fear of God: The people set free to take the best advantage to proceed in judgement against him, 2 Chron. 21.10. Josh. 21.13. This in the Abridg. Remonst.

Page 23. 24. (say they) For any King to take up Armes, or in any other way endeavour to uphold the interest of his will & power against the common interest of his people, such a person may be justly said to be guilty of the highest Treason, against the highest Law amongst men, & that the publick justice of a Nation cannot be satisfied, the bloud avenged, the wrath of God for the same appeased, without judgement executed against h • m. For this they quote Numb. 25.4. Deut. 19.13. 1 Sam. 3.5 6.14.

If the summe or main of publick interest is conteined in this, that in all matters of publick concernment, the trust thereof should be in the peoples Representors, and not in a single person and his Councill, and if it were so tyrannicall in the King, for the advance of his interest, to endeavour to make voide the power of Parliaments, so as they should not check or restrain him from having this trust resting in him alon • , without limitation or giving account to any on earth; and there having been so much bloud shed in our contest against these things, then how can you but blush, when you consider that your Generall doth the very same things? plucking up by the roots the very summe and main of publick interest, placing it so in his own brest, that
nothing can be done without him, whereby we are brought under greater slavery than in the day of the King.

You opposed the King first because he assumed that trust wholly to himself, which of right should be in the peoples Representors: And 2. when he condesended so low, as to give way they should have the exercise thereof, yet so as not without him; you would not allow of that, but maintained the Parliament in their exercising this trust without him, because yee judged it most safe to publick Interest: yet the same power you denyed to him, your Gen • rall hath assumed to himself, and you uphold him in it, whereby we are enslaved to his arbitrary will and lust, as the King endeavoured to do in that day; and although he doth not say (as he did) that no lawfull power on earth ought to attach or meddle with him, for this or any other evil; yet by his power in the Army, Militia, and Navy, he hath so strengthened him self, that except the Lord do wonderfully step in to deliver us, we shall be kept under a perpetui • y of slavery and bondage; for his saying he will lay down his • l • bones in upholding his usurpt Government, declares plainly he designes to perpe • uate his oppression upon us. But as the former Tyrants Charrot wheels wer • by degrees taken off till he came down to the block, so the disappointments the Lord gives your Master in his undertakings tending to his abasement, are sad presages that if he persist to walk in the Kings steps, he must partake of his punishment.

Now if a lawfull Magistrate doing thus, forfeits all that power and trust he had, and sets the people free from the bonds of Covenant and Peace between them, to take their best advantage to proceed in judgement against him, if this might be done to the green tr • e, viz. a lawfull power, then what will become of your drye Protector an unlawfull power, neither chosen nor entrusted by God nor the people, but hath meerly usurpt it, and rooted up these very foundations of right and freedome, setting up his Arbitrary lust above all law, and is so strengthned and upheld in your assistance in this Tyranny, that the supream Authority, the peoples Rep • esentors, cannot come together with freedome, to call him to account, nor dare any other Court of Judicature proceed against him to give redresse in these things. Wherefore by your own words, the p • ople are free from subjection to such a usurpt power as his is▪ and may take their best advantage when they shall have opportunity to throw off his Yoak, and bring him to condigne punishment: And so much the rather, because he hath bin formerly so great an A • sertor of these Liberties for the people, in opposition to this Tyranny and Oppress • on in the King. Now for him after all, to tread in the very same and broader paths of Tyranny and Oppression, for the advance of
his private interest, surely his judgement and condemnation must needs be much more righteous, and the publick justice of the Nation, and the wrath of God con lesse be satisfied or appeased, if there be not a proceeding against him, for if Scripture will justifie the former, the latter will be much more clear and without exception.

div.head: And in the 8. and 9. Pages of the Abridgment of this Remonstrance, they hold forth its dangerous to receive the King unto tearms of agreement and peace, &c.
div.p:
And after this accommodation to s • tisfie the people, you shall disbād your forces, you are at the Kings curtesie still, and are but where you were at fi • st, but the King in much fairer possibility to revive the old quarrell, and carry it without fighting, for after so much bloud and trouble for nothing, it is not like you will finde a competent party for the opposing of him, &c. Besides these we cannot but consider
the vast possibilities after his restitution, to make or use factions among your selves, and your adherents, and do not all men acknowledge him most exquisite at it, & if h • had that faculty to avayl at distance, much more in your bosoms, each party will be apt to strive, which shall most, and first comply with him, of which y • u and we have seen sad experiences already, yet we refus'd ought of private contract or trust with him & his, & all was with saving for the publi{que} Interest, &c. To conclude we confess our fears from the Act of this Parliaments unlimited continuance, if he forme a ballancing party in the house of Commons for his Interest, that which should be our conservative would be our bain, and yet we should be debared from change of Medicine, or if a period be set to this Parliament, and no provision for certain suecession, and sitting of Parliaments; withous dependance on the Kings will, or if no provision for a more due consti • ution, by more equall elections, than the success will be les hopefull, & safe then the present, and you have not in this Treaty made any provision for these things; but to proceed to sh • w the certain insecurity to publiq • e interest, in accommodation with a r • stitution of the King, for you the supream Judicature of the Kingdome (when he is in your power to do justice upon) to decline that w • y, and instead thereof, to seek to him your prisoner in way of Treaty, what speaks it lesse, than that • he is indeed above all humane Justi • e, not accountable to, or punishable by any power on ea • th, whatsoever he doth, and that Kings cannot erre or do wrong, whereas
one example of this kinde made, would be of more terrour and avail, than the execution of his whole party, yea, than all satisfaction you can imagine, &c.

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
If it were so probable that the King who had so much lost the love of the Parliament and people in his raising a war and shedding of bloud, would have gained su • h a party to his interest as might undoubtedly have been to publick prejudice, th • n much more will a single person in that power gain upon them, who (though indeed he be more) yet is not so seemingly blame-worthy as the King was, so that by this
foregoing and what comes after in the Remon • trance, as als • by the Act of Pa • liament 17. of M •• c • 1648 for the abolishing of Kingly Government, and your declaration in Scotland, &c. That you judged it most safe to publ que Intere t, that the N • tion should be governed by the peoples R • p •• s • ntors succe • siv • ly chosen, without a single person and his Councill. Now if not only from natural wisedom, but that which is spiritual also, you would contend so ea •
nestly for publick Libe • ty against Tyranny, how comes it th • n to passe you a • t so contrary now? Su • ly that glorious presence of the Lord with you (when appearing to be acted by this cl • ar and honest spirit) compared with his eminent departing f • om you, since your very fir • t declension from it, to act upon the Monarchi • al foundation, declares plainly he approves not of your actions. And whereas you say it would be our bain to want provision for certain succession and equall elections, of the peoples Representors, &c. in case the King had been received and invested with that power over Pa • liaments which he had so much contended for. Is it not as mu • h destructive to the peoples Lib • rty, for you to m • ntain the same power in your Generall, which you then judged so pernicious in th • King?

For just laws being from God (Themis the daughter of Jove) who is not under them, owns not his subjection to God, whereas God hath not put that distance betwixt Kings and other men, they are his brethren though his subjects, Deut. 17 ult. so David calls his subjects, 1 Chron. 28.2. if any King, because a King, be punishable by men, then all Kings are so, and no man may justly punish any King: But when a people to be punisht shall spare their King, as Saul (the people then admiring happily the persons, aswell as government of Kings) spared Agagg, Sam. 15.9. But we find Gods instruments fixing more solemne punishments on wicked Kings, than on their wicked people, Joshua slaies all their Kings, Josh. 11.17. being thirty one, 11. ch. vlt. and hangs up some, Josh. 10.24, 28, 30, 40. Mideon more solemnly executes the Kings of Midean, then other enemies, Judg 8.5, 21. Ehud slayes King Eylon. Judg. 3.21. so Jehoiadah and the Commanders put Athaliah to death 2 Chron. 23.14. And if it be said these two last Princes came to the crown by force and bloud, and so were without a title, it may be replyed, that such was the enterance of the first of the English, French, &c. Royall race, from whom the present Kings claim, but
further, these two had reigned, and the people been subjects to them (which makes the most usuall Title) the one for 18. years, Judges 3.14. the other 6. years, 2 Chron. 22.12. Jehu did slay both the Kings of Israell, and Judah 2 King. 9. And Asaph prayes Psalm. 83.11. that Nobles and Princes of enemies, may be used after former examples, and as this rank of men is opposing Christ in the last times, so are they by him, and his people to be punished, Psal. 2. Psal. 110.5. The Lord at thy right hand shall strike thorough Kings in the day of thy wrath, Psal. 149.8, 9. to bind their Kings in chains, and Nobles in fetters of Iron, to execute upon them the judgement written this honour have the Saints, the fowls are invited to eat the flesh of kings, and captaines are slaughtered by the Lamb, Rev. 19.17, 18. It could not have been without scandall, if David had slain Saul because a private person, and under personall hate and injury, it would have savoured of ambition or revenge; And it was onely declared against the succeeding of his Race, not the continuance of his person, but the state and people, not taking course against Saul, did smart in his otherway of punishment. It appears David forbore him not meerly out of Reverence to his Authority, for he took up armes to defend himself against him, and would (if that part of people would have joyned) have maintained Kailah against him, 1 Sam. 23 Now all this was co •
trary to subjection, and intimates that if David had been put to it, and he could not otherwise have escaped, would have used force against Saul, &c.
Page 10. Abridg. Remonst. They do fully acknowledge the power to be in the peoples Representatives in Parliament, and that the executing of justice and shewing mercy was in them.

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
If you might honestly bring these Scriptures as examples and rules, to encourage and stir up the Parliament to execute justice upon the King, who endeavoured by force to uphold himself in that tyrannicall power he assumed over the Nation, and laid so much weight thereon, that you as it were told them if they refused you would do it your selves. Then why may not we whose hearts, purses, and prayers, were engaged with you in that work, and yet thorough grace are kept faithful to those honest principles, as honestly oppose your Generall, who contrary to Declarations, Acts of Parliament, and Engagements, &c. sealed with so much bloud, and without the appointment of God or his people, hath usurpt the dignity and Office of chief Magistrate over the Nation, broken down the foundations of right and freedome, so lately centended for, with a vast expence of bloud and treasure, trampled upon that h •
