nest spirit in them turned out of the little Parliament, who were going on in the work and cause of God, casting some of them into prison upon that very account, and doth exercise the same and worse Tyranny and Oppression in the very forme and method the King went in; opposing the work and cause of God in this day, and acting as upon the foundation so from a tincture, of the spirit, of the beast, and Antichrist: Th • se things considered, why may we
not as honestly not onely pray, but endeavour all we can, that he may be used after the examrle of former Tyrants and Ʋsurpers, and rejoyce to see the judgments written against such wretches, executed upon him, who hath so caused the honour of Christ to suffer by his Apostacy, and building again the things that were once destroyed; & if after your extracting the very spirit of these Scriptures, you declare that Saul who was annointed by God to be King, might be opposed; then by the same argument your Protector and unlawfull power may be opposed much more. And therefore in vain do you and others urge the 13. Rom. and other Scriptures against those w • o oppose your Generall, as resisters of Magistracy; for he hath no more right to the power he hath, than a Thief to that purse which he hath taken from another on the high-way, for he is neither called of God, chosen by the people, nor hath he gained it by Conquest, one of which ingredients must needs be in his exaltation, if ye will convince us he is a lawfull power.

Page 11. They desire the costly pomp in the Court may be suspended for a good number of years, and that Revenue to be disposed towards publick charges, debts and damages for the easing of the people, &c.

And do also desire a period to be put to that Parliament, and that care be taken for future equal elections, and that none should elect or be elected, that were engaged in the late war against the Parliament, nor any other who oppose that settlement promised, and that the future power in Parliaments might be cleared, as supream onely, and that no foundations of common right might be given away, &c-

And that no King be hereafter admitted but upon election of, and as upon trust from the people, by such their Representatives, not without fi • st disclaming all pretence to a negative voice, against the determination of the Cōmons in Parliament, and this to be done in some forme more clear than he • etofore in the Coronation O • th.

We propound these matters of General settlement to b • provided by the Authority of th • Commons in that Parliament, & be to further established by a generall contract, or agreement of the people with
their subscriptions thereto, & that no King be admitted to the Crown, nor other person to any office of publique trust without expresse accord, and subscription to the same.

For our parts let but that way of justice be effectually prosecuted, and the settlement of the publique Interest be assured to us, and the Nation, we shall desire discharge from our present service, &c.

div.head: Annot.
div.p: Do not these d • sires of yours condemne your present practice, who now main • ain your Generall in his wastefull spending a great part of the publick revenue, to uphold the pride, pomp and luxury of his Court.

But contrary to the very spirit of this your Generall in usurping the power into his own hand, doth not onely oppose this settlement, but robs the peoples Trustees of that supream power which only and of right belongs to them, and will let none be chosen nor sit, but such as own and acknowledge his power by indenting they will not alter it, as in Instr. Gov. Article 34. neither will he let any thing passe that is agreed on in his Parliament, for the good of the Nation if it clash therewith, as it appeares A • ticle of the lostr. 24. which is grea • er slavery than when we were under the King, and for you or any other to consent hereto, is to give away th • foundations of common right and freedome, which you seemed so much to contend for.

Your Protecto • contrary to this hath forced himsel • and government upon the people, without the accord, subscription, or election of themselves, or Representors, and hath usurped to him • elfe a Negative voice, and thereby doth con • radict what ever is done by his pre • ended Parliament if it comply not with his Inte est.

Your profession is fair, why do you not then make use of you • swords to performe your wordes, but unworthily suffer your fellow Souldiers, and others, the f • i • hfull Patriots, and assertors of the N • tions interest to be persecuted and
imprisoned for pressing after the publi{que} good, according to the true intent and spirit of your desires made known herein. Is it not rather your duty now to Remonstrate to your Protector, as then you did to the Parliament, & say as the people did in Jonath. case to Saul 1 Sam. 14.4, 5. shall our brethren who with us have wrought so great salvation in Israel, be thus persecuted, imprisoned, and unworthily dealt withall; and so rescue your brethren from the hand of violence.

div.head: In the Petition annexed to the Agreement of the people, presented to the Commons of England in Parliament, on Satturday January 20. 1648.
div.p:
We hold our selves obliged to give the people all assurance possible that our opposing the corrupt closure endeavoured with the King was not in design, to hinder peace and settlement, (thereby to render our employments as Soldiers necessary to be continued) and that neither that extraordinary course we have taken, nor any other proceeding of ours, have been intended for the setting up of any particular party, or Interest, by or with which to uphold our selves, in power and dominion over the Nation, but that it was, and is the desire of our hearts in all we have done (with the hindering of that eminent evill and destructive conjunction with the King) to make way for the settlement of the peace and Government of the Kingdome upon
grounds of common freedome and safety: And be cause our former overtures to that purpose (being in only general termes, and not reduced to a certainty of perticulars fit for practice) might possibly be understood, but as plausible pretences, not intended really to be put into effect; we have thought it our duty to draw out those generalls into an entire forme of particulars ascertained with such circumstance, as may make it effectively practicable, &c. We are far from such a spirit, as possitively to impose our private apprehensions, upon the judgements of any in the kingdome that have not forfeited their freedome, and much lesse upon your selves, neither are we apt in any wise, to insist upon circumstantiall things, or ought that is not evidently fundamentall to that publique interest, for which you and we have declared and engaged: But in this tender of it we humbly desire.

1. That whether it shall be fully approved by you, and received by the people (as it now stands) or not, it may yet remain upon Record before you, a perpetuall Witnesse of our reall intentions, and utmost endeavours, for a sound and equall settlement, and as a Testimony whereby all men may be assu • ed, what we are willing and ready to acquiesse in, and their jealousies satisfied, or their mouthes stopt, who are apt to think, or say, we have no bottome:

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
You say your hindering that corrupt closure with the King, and all your extraordinary courses and proceedings therein, was onely to make way, that the peace and Government of the Nation, might be settled upon grounds of publique freedome and safety, and not setting up of any particular party or interest, to uphold your selves in power and dominion over the Nation. And this you declare as a perpetuall witnesse of your reall intentions, to bottom in that sound and equal way of settlement, by the peoples Representors, freely and successively chosen into the supream Authority, without a single person and his Councill, by a Negative voice, to controule them, or to pick and cull them for his interest; this comes freely from your selves, for your own vindication, to stop the mouthes, and satisfie the jealousies
of those, who it seems then feared what now is come upon them: But do you not contrary to all this, maintain and uphold your Protector and his Councill, a private and particular interest, who have Arbitrarily usurped to themselves, power and dominion over the Nation, th • reby rooting up that very foundation of common right and freedome, placed in the peoples Representors, ye so much declared you would bottome in; so that they cannot be chosen by them, much lesse sit with freedome and safety, except they first submit to his Government, which if they should do, they not onely strengthen him in his usurpation, but do betray and give a way the just Rig • ts and Liberties of the people, into his hands, after our great contending for them, with so vast an expence of bloud and treasure.

div.head: Here followes the Agreement of the People.
div.p:
Page 7. God having so far owned our Cause, as to deliver the enemies therof into our hands, we do now hold our selves bound in mutuall duty to each other, to take the best care we can for the future, to avoid both the danger of returning into
a slavish condition, and the chargable remedy of another war. For as it cannot be imagined, that so many of our Countrey men would have opposed us in this quarrell, if they had understood their own good, so may we hopefully promise to our selves, that when our common right and priviledges shall be cleared, their endeavours will be disappointed, that seek to make themselves our Masters; since therefore our former oppressions, and not yet ended troubles, have been occasioned, either by want of frequent Nationall meetings in Councill, or by the undue or unequall constitution thereof, or by rendring those meetings ineffectuall. We are fully agreed and resolved (God willing) to provide that hereafter that our Representatives be neither left to an uncertainty for time, nor be unequally constituted, nor made uselesse, to the ends for which they are appointed, &c. And so they go on, presenting what they had agreed upon under ten generall Heads, whereof onely some of the greater conce • nment (for brevity sake) are here mentioned.

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
You having at that time a potent Enemy to deal withall, your care was good to mak • use of your power, for prevention of future slavery, and embroilment of another war: But now the case is otherwise; this potent Enemy being
vanquished, there is none but your Protector, who doth oppose the settling of us in our rights and liberties, against whom there needs not the like force and power, having no party to strengthen his hands but your selves, and therefore if you withdraw your assistance from him (who seeks to make himself our master as well as yours) there can be no fear of another war; but if you still adhere to uphold his usurped interest, who hath no more right to the power he hath than any of you; and upon this accompt another warr ensue, your selves are guilty of all the bloud that shall be spilt, which we hope you will not do, if you so well understood your good, as you pretended to do when you spake these words; for as you did then, so we do now reckon it our duty, to endeavour that the Representors of the people, who have not forfeited their liberty, should not onely meet, but be preserved from the power of any that would endeavour to hinder them in their Counsells and actings for the glory of God and the publique good, and it is your duty according to these your expressions, to be assisting to us therein, that so our fears and jealousies may be removed, otherwise we shall have ju • t cause to conclude, that your intentions were indeed to hold up your selves in power, and to Lord it over the people by the sword, notwithstanding all your fair pretences in your overtures, and expressions mentioned in this Agreement.

First, that to prevent the many inconveniences apparently arising from the large continuance of the same persons in supream Authority, this present Parliament end, and
dissolve, upon, or before the last day of Aprill 1649.

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
And is it not much more inconvenient and dangerous, that your Protector, who was chosen neither by God nor his people, should impose his Government upon
us during life, with a provision for his successors to do the same.

Thirdly, that the people do of course choose themselves a Representative once in two years, & shall meet for that purpose upon the first Thursday in every second May, &c. And the Representative so chosen to meet the second Thursday in June following, at the usuall place in Westminster, &c.

Fiftly, that each Representative shall within twenty dayes after their first meeting, appoint a councill of State, for the managing publique Affairs, untill the tenth day after the meeting of the next Representative, unlesse that next Representative think fit to put an end to that Trust sooner, and the same Councill to Act, and proceed therein according to such instructions and limitations, as the Representative shall give and not otherwise.

Sixtly, that in each intervall betwixt Bienniall Representatives the Councill of State (in case of immen • nt danger, or extreme necessity) may sommons a Representative to be forth with chosen, and to meet so, as the session thereof continue not above fourscore dayes, and so as it dissolve at least fifty dayes before the appointed time for the next Bienniall Representative, and upon the 50th. day so proceeding it shall dissolve, of course, if not otherwise dissolved sooner.

Eightly, that the Representative have, and shall be understood to have the supream Trust, in order to the preservation and governm • nt of the whole, and that their power extend without the consent or concurrence of any other person, or persons, to the erecting and abolishing of Courts of Justice and publique Offices, and to the enacting, repealing, and declaring of Laws, and the highest, and finall Judgement,
concerning all naturall and civill things, but not concerning things spirituall and Evangelical, provided that even in things naturall and civill, these six particulars next following are, and shall be understood to be excepted and reserved for our Representatives. Four whereof are onely m • ntioned.

div.head: Annot.
div.p: By these following particulars you do acknowledge, that all just power is originally and essentially in the people, and that their free choice or consent by their Representors, is the on • ly originall and foundation of all ju t Government, so that Rulers proceed from them, & not they from their Rulers; as also that its very unsafe and dangerous, that this power of managing publique affairs, should be in the hands of any, but such as they entrust. Yet how contrary hereunto your actings are let all men judge; For hath not your Protector and his creatures, or rather his creators, some of your chief Officers with others of his Councill (so called) assumed to themselves the supream Trust, in order to the preservation and • overnment of the people, and improving the Militia, wch should be for the peoples defence, not to the quelling of their Enemies, but the faithfull Assertors and Keepers of their Liberties, and nothing can be done, but what subjects to their restrictions.

First, we do not impower them to imprest or constrain any person to serve in forreign war, either by Sea or Land, nor for any Military service within the Kingdome, save that they may take order for the Training and exercising the people in a Military way, to be in rediness for resisting forreign invasions, suppressing of suddain or for assisting in execution of Law, &c.

Fourthly, That in any Laws hereafter to be made, no person by vertue of any Tenure, Grant, Charter Patent, degree of Birth, shall be priviledged from subj • ction thereto, or from being bound thereby, as well as others.

div.head: Annot.
div.p: Yet you do that your selves, or suffer your Protector in doing of it, which you would not allow to the supream Authority of the Nation, witnesse the fruitlesse expedition both to the Streights, Hispaniola, and Jamica, which exorbitant practice is by the Law of God counted man-stealing, and punishahle with death, Exod. 21.15.

Fifthly, That the Representative may not give judgment upon any mans person or estate where no Law hath before provided, save only in calling to accompt, and punishing pub • ique Officers, for abusing or • ayling th • ir trust.
Six • hly, That no Representative may in any wise render up, or give, or take away any foundations of common right and safety conteyned in this agreement, &c.
And if it was an evill to passe judgment upon any without Law, much more to imprison the faithfull Patriots of the Country against Law, and never bring them to a due tryall.

Tenthly, It is agreed that whosoever shall by force of Armes resist the Orders of the next or any future Representative (except in case where such Representative shal evidently render up, or give, or take away the foundations of common right, liberty and safety conteined in this Agreement) shall forth with after his or their such resistance
loose the benefit and protection of the Lawes, and shall be punished with death as an Enemy and Traytor to the Nation. All these we do accompt, and declare to be fundamental to our common Right, Liberty and Safety, and therefore do both agree thereunto, and resolve to maintain the same as God shall enable us, &c.

And if unlawfull in the peoples Representors to take, or give away any of these foundations of right and freedome, and may be opposed upon that accompt, than much more may your Gen • rals upstart power which hath raised it selfe out of the ruines of the peoples liberties, and is rather the excressence than any part of the essence of a Lawfull power.

div.head: And in the Declaration annexed to this Agreement coming after
div.p: Page 7. To the end that mens jealousies and fears may b • removed, concerning any intentions in us to ho d up our se • ves in power, to oppresse or domineere over the people by the sword, and that all men may understand those grounds of peace, and government, whereupon they may rest assured, we shall for our parts acqui • sse; we have spent much time to prepare, and have at last (thorough the blessing of God) finisht a draught of such settlement, in the nature of an Agreement of he people for a peace amongst themselves, which we have lately presented to the Honourable the Commons assembled in Parliament; and do herewith tender to the people of this Nation; which contains the best and most hopefull foundations for the future peace, and well government of the Nation, that we can devise or think on, within the line of humane power, and such wherein all the people intrested in this land, that have not particular interests of advantage, and power over others, devided from that which is common and publick, are indifferently & equally provided for, &c.

But if God shall (in his righteous judgement towards this land) suffer the people to be so blinded, as not to see their own common good and freedome, endeavoured to be provided for therein; or any to be so deluded (to their own and publique prejudice) as to make opposi • ion thereto, whereby the eff • ct of it be hindered, we have yet by the preparation and tender of it, discharged our consciences to God, and duty to our Native Countrey, in our utmost endeavours for a settlement (to the best of our understandings) unto a just publique interest, and hope we shall be acquitted before God, and good men, of any further trouble, distractions, or miseries to the Kingdome, which may arise thorough the neglect, and rejection thereof, or opposition thereto, &c.

Page 29. We (for our parts) are far from any desire or thought, to assume or exercise a law-giving, or judiciall power over the Kingdome, or to meddle in any thing, save the fundamentall settling of that power, in the most equall and hopefull way for common right, freedome and safety, as in this Agreement, &c.

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
And if to take the power out of the hands of a singl • person and his Councill, who did (and naturally do) make use thereof to their own particular and private interests, and placing it in the hands of the peopl • s Repr • s • ntors, freely, and successiv ly chosen, was the most hopefull and b st foundation, that within the line of humane power could be devised, or thought on for the future well government, and peace of the Nation, and that which provided for all who minded publique good, and had not particular interests and desire of advantage to themselves, and of pow • r over others; and so much good laid up herein, as it had been a Judgement from the Lord upon the Nation, to suffer the people to be so farr blinded, and deluded, to their own and publique prejudice, to put off, oppose, and hinder, this good and freedome coming to them, in this safe and settled way to publique interest: And your edneavours after, and propounding this way of se • t • emen • , such a discharge of your Conscience and duty to God, and your Countrey, and that which would acquit you before him and good men, from blame of any futher trouble, &c. to the Nation, which might arise in rejecting and opposing of it. And that you
had not a thought or desire, to assume or exercise, a law-giving, or judiciall power over the Nation, and would meddle no further, than to see it settled in the peoples Representors, as the most hopefull way for the pr • servation of common right and freedome. Then what is the reason, you have now so soon altered if not your judgement, to be sure your practice, in upholding your Generall, who hath made hims lf Chief Magistrate, and thereby hath usurped this power out of that way, wherein you acknowledged it most safe, placing it in himself, and Councill, as it was in the King, when you thus complained against it? Now if from a tincture of that spirit that ranne in the King and his party, which you have received from their Houses, Parks, and Revenves (Deut. 7.26.) you are thus turned about to build upon their foundation, and to walk in those wayes of Tyranny, to the hindring publique w lfare, you so condemned in them; Then assure your selves, if you persist herein, there are a Remnant whom the Lord keeps fai hfull to the true interest of Christ, and the Nation, who being more refined in that spirit, and those principles you here seem to be acted by, that by his assistance, do all you can to hinder them, will never give him nor you re t, till they see this foundation of Tyranny you have l •• ely mounted upon, and the things you have built thereon, destroyed; and the liberties you seemed to contend so highly for, secured in the best and safest way, and most agreeable to the true intent and spirit of your Remonstrances, Engagements, and Declarations, so farre as they accord with the Scriptures.

div.head:
From the Agents of Lievt. Generalls Regiment, Commissary Generalls Regiment, Collonel Fleetwoo •
's Regiment, Collonel Whaley's Regiment, Collonel Rich his Regiment.
For the Noble and highly Honoured, the Free borne people of England in their rtspective Counties and divisions these.
div.p: For your sakes, our friends, estates and lives have not been dear untous, for your safety and freedome we have chearfully endured hard labours, and run most desperate hazards, and in comparison to your peace and freedom, we neither do, nor ever shall value our dearest blood, and we professe our bowels are, and have been troubled, and our hearts pained within us, in s • eing, and considering that you have b • en so long bereaved of these fruits and ends of all our labours and h • zz • rds. We cannot but sympathize with y • u in your miseries, and Oppressions; its grief and vex • tion of heart to us, to receive your meat, and monyes, whil • st you have no advantage, nor yet the foundations of your peace and freedome, surely laid.

And therefore upon most serious consideration, that your principle Right, most essentiall to your well being, is the clearn • ss • , certainty, suffi • iency, and freedome of your power, in your Representatives in Parliament, &c. And minding, that for this Ri • ht of ours, and yours: we engaged our lives: For the King raised the warr against you, and your Parliament, upon this ground, that he would not suffer your Representatives to proceed or your peace, safety and freedome, that were then in danger by dispencing the Militia; and otherwise according to their trust, • nd for the maintenance and defence of that power and right of yours, we hazzarded all that was dear to us; and God hath been witnesse to the justice of our Cause. And further, minding that the onely effectuall means, to settle a just and lasting Peace, to obtain remedy for all your grievances, and to prevent future Oppressions, is; the making clear and secure the power that you betrust to your Representatives in Parliament. Upon all these grounds, we propound your joyning with us in the Agreement herewith sent unto you, that by vertue thereof, we may have Parliaments certainly called, and have the time of their sitting and ending certain; and their power and trust, clear and unqu • stionable; that after they may remove your burthens, &c. That there may be no grounds for future quarrells or contentions, to occasion
warr or bloodshed, and we desire you would consider, that as these things wherein we offer to agree with you, are the fruits and ends of the victories which God hath given us, so the settlement of these are the most absolute means to preserve you, and your posterity, from sl •
very, oppression, distraction and trouble. By this those whom your selves shall choose, shall have power to restore you to, and secure you in all your rights, and they sha • l be in a capacity to taste of Subjection as well as Rule, and so shall be equally concerned with your selves, in all they do, for they must equally suff • r with you under any common burdens, and partake with you in any freedomes, and by this they shall be disi • abled to defraud or wrong you, when the Laws shall bind all without priviledge, or exemption; and by this your consciences sha l be free from Tyranny and oppression, and those occasions of endless strifes and bloody warrs sha • l be perfectly removed, &c.

And if any shall enquire why we undertake to offer this Agreement, we must pro • esse we are sensible that you have been so often deceived with Declarations and Remonstrances, and fed with vain hopes, that you have reason to abandon all confidence in any persons whatsoever, from whom you have no other security of their intending your freedome then bare D •• larations: And t • erefore as our Consciences witness that in simplicity, and integrity of heart, we have proposed lately in the Case of the Army stated your freedome, and deliverance from slavery, Oppression, and all burdens, so we desire to give you satisfying assurance thereof by this Agreement, whereby the found tions of your freedome provided in the Case, &c. shall be settled unalterably, &c.
Agents coming from other Regiments unto us have subscrib • d t • e Agreement, to be propos • d to their respective Regiments and yo • .

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
And doth not your Protector in this day bere • ve us of the very same foundation, of Right and fr • edome, which we hoped to receive as the fruit o • our labour, &c. Why then are you not grieved, & why do you not stand up with the like Resolution and Courage now as th • n? And if you hazarded all that was near and dear unto you in opposing th • King, because he bounded the peoples Representors, and would not suffer them to dispose the Militia according to their Trust, for the safety of the Nation. And if t • e Lord hath borne witnesse to the justice of your Consein so doing, ought you not then in this day to stand up upon the same grounds ag • inst your Protector who hath assumed the whole power of the M • l • tia (as the King then endeavoured to do) and thereby hath wrested the power and
trust thereof out of our Representors hands, which of right belongs to them. And will not the Lord (think you) own you in opposing him, as formerly against the King: And if you thought in that day that the onely effect • uall meanes to settle a just and lasting peace, and to prevent future Oppression, Warr, and bloud-shed, was to secure and clear the power betrusted with such Representors distinct from a single person, and his Councill; and this of so high concernment, that you judged it Necessary to stirr up the people by this Agreement to assist you therein. Is there not then upon the same grounds, and for the same ends, cause for us to minde you of these things, and to call upon you at this day to do your duty, to helpe pull down the like usurped power now in a Protector, which you then opposed in the King; and which he is not able to uphold without you? For if you unanimously declare your selves for the good of your Countrey, against these Innovators; you may in the mean time, till the peoples Representors, who have not forfeited their liberty, can meet and settle things upon their due Basis, put a stop upon all the publique Revenues, which these men have diverted out of the right channell, to themselves; empowering such as are confiding men with Receipt thereof, in d • ing whereof you shall by the Lords assistance, recover our lost liberties without expence of Treasure, or shedding of bloud▪ For it is well known that your Protector and his Courtiers, are not so well beloved, either at home or abroad, as to raise a considerable force in opposition to you, and the Countrey herein. And further to move you hereunto, consider the deplorable estate of our Nation, and let your Bowells yearn towards us your fellow Commoners, who are not onely made Vassalls as to our persons and liberties, but our estates wasted, our publique Treasures exhausted, many of our ships decayed and lost, and thousands of our men slain and perished in a sinfull and fruitlesse expedition to Hispaniola: Whereby through the righteous judgement of God, our Nation, which was formerly a terrour to all the Nations round about, is now become a scorn: So tha • we have not onely lost our liberties and estates, but God, his Name, and Glory also. A • l which considered, we doubt not but you will have such a deep sense upon your spirits, of the dishonour brought upon the Cause of God, and the unavoidable ruine which hangeth over the Nation (if God prevent not) as will awaken you, and stir up your former Zeal for God and your Countrey But if after all this you shall fit still, and neglect to do your Duty: then know it for a tru h, that the Lord will raise up Deliverance some other way, and that speedily; and you and your house shall perish, as Mordecay said to Esther, Esther 4 14.

div.head: Four Acts of Parlament past after the Death of the late King.
First that of January 30. 1648. the same day, or the day after the late King was Beheaded.
div.p: VVHereas Charles Stuart King of England, being for the notorious Treasons, Tyrannies, and Murders committed by him in the late unnaturall and cruell Warrs condemned to Death, &c. Be it enacted and ordained by this present Parliament, and by the Authority of the same, that no person, or persons whatsoever, do presume to Proclaim, Declare, Publish, or any way promote Charles Stuart, Sonne of the said Charles, commonly called the Prince of Wales, or any other person, to be King or Chief Magistrate, of England, or Ireland, or of any the Dominions belonging to them, or either of them, by colour of Inheritance, Succession, Election, or of any other Claims whatsoever; without the free consent of the people in Parliament; first had, and signified, by a particular Act or Ordinance, for that purpose, any Statute, Law, Usage, or Custome to the contrary hereof in any wise notwithstandding. And be it further Enacted and Ordained, that whosoever shall contrary to this Act Proclaim, Declare, Publish, or any way promote the said Charles Stuart the Sonne, or any other person to be King, or Chief M • gistrate of England, or of Ireland, &c. without the said consent in Parliament si • nified as aforesaid, shall be deemed, and judged a Traitor to the Commonwealth, and shall suffer pain • of death, and such other punishments as belong to the Crimes of high Treason: And all Officers, aswell Civill as Military, and all other well aff cted persons, are hereby Authorised and required, forthwith to apprehend all such Off • nders, and to bring them in safe cust • dy to the next Justice of peace, that they may be proceeded against accordingly.

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
Then by this and the other following Acts not yet repealed by Parliamen • , or any thing that was like a Parliament, being also b • und by his own and his Creatures I • str. of Government, Article 6. which saies, that no Law shall be altered, suspended, abrogated, or repealed, or new Laws made, nor any Taxe, Charge, or imposition laid upon the people, but by common consent in Parliament. Your Protector having usurpt the power of Chief Magistracy over the Nation, without the Consent of the peopl • s Representors, who are the Supream Authority, is a Triator; and so were all those who were ayders of Abet • ors,
to and Proclaimors of him: And do deserve death, and the other punishments as belong to the Crime of high Treason: And it is as lawfull for any well-affected person, or Officr to apprehend him and his Abettors, to bring them before t • e next Justice of the peace, to be proceeded against accordingly, as to have apprehended Charles Stu • rt or any other person who would have proclia'md him King or chief Magistrate in that day.
The Second Acte past March 17. 1648. entituled An Act for the abolishing the Kingly Office in England.

Whereas Charles Stuart late King of England and Ireland, &c. is hereby declared to be justly condemned and put to death &c. for many Treasons, &c. Whereby his posterity, and all others pretending Title under him, are become uncapable of the said Crowns, &c. or to have the Name, Title, Stile or Dignity of King, &c or to have the Power or Dominion of the s id Kingdomes, &c. or the Honours, Mannors, Lands, Tenements, Possessions and Heriditaments, belonging or appertaning to the said Crown of England, &c. And whereas it is, and hath been found by experience, that the Office of a King in this Nation and Ireland, and to have the power thereof in any single person is unnecessary, burthensom • and dangerous to the liberty, safety and publique inter • st of the people, and that for the most part, use hath been made of the R • gall power, and Prerogative, to oppress • , impoverish, and insl • ve the Subject. And that usually and naturally, any one person in such power makes it his interest, to encroach upon the just freedome and liberty of the people, and to promote the setting up of their own will and power above the Laws, that so they might ensl • ve the Kingdoms to their own lusts. B • it therefore enacted and declared, by this present Parliament, &c. That the Office of a king in this Nation shall n t henceforth reside in, or be exercised by any one single person. And that no one person whatsoever, shall or may hold the Office, Stile, Dignity, Power or Authority of a King, &c. And if any person or persons shall by force of Armes or otherwise, be ayding, and assisting to any persons, that sh • ll by any way and means, be promoting any to that Office, (or to that purp • se) That then every such offence shall be de •
med and adjudged high Treason, &c,

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
And may not the Free-born people of the Nation, who have had such renewed and wo • ull experience, by the evill carriage and practises of your Protector since he usurped the power of chief Magistrate over them, tending chiefly for the advance of his Interest: Say upon good grounds, that it is indeed unnecessary, burthensome
and dangerous to the liberty, safety, and publique interest of the people, to have such a power in the hands of a single person. For is it not as evident as she Sun in the firmament, that as his Predecessors formerly did, so he doth oppresse, impoverish, and enslave the Nation to his lusts, in setting up his Arbitrary will and power, contrary to, and above the Law, as may appear by severall instances, if there were roome to mention them: Wherefore have we not good reason to abominate and oppose this power as in him, so also in the hands of any other person whatsoever, though never so Godly; and to be confided in, till our Lord Jesus Christ doth come whose right it is?

div.head: The Third Act of Parliament past 14. May 1649. which in a manner is all one with the Fourth; and therefore not Transcribed.
The Fourth Act of Parliament past July 17. 1649.
div.p: Whereas the Parliament hath abolished the kingly Office in England, and Ireland, &c. And having Resolved, and Declared, that the people for the future, shall be Governed by its own Representatives, and Nationall meetings in Councill, chosen and entrusted by them. For that purpose hath settled the Government in a Common-weal • h and Free-State without a King, and House of Lords: Be it Enacted, &c. That if any person shall malitiously, or advisedly publish by writing, printing, or open declaring, That the said Government is Tyrannicall, Usurped, or Unlawfull; And that the Commons ass • mbled in Parliament, are not the Supream Authority of this Nation, or shall Plot, Contrive, or endeavour to stir up and raise force, &c. That then every such offence shall be taken, d • emed, and adjudged by Authority of this Parliament, to be High Treason.

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
The Generallity of Well-affected people in the Nation, who went along in the Work and Cause of God in that day with you, approved of, and consented to these four Acts and Engagement, which contein in them a full provision, for the keeping out of Monarchy, and the p wer from being in the hands of a single person and his Councill; which they saw (as by their experience in the late King and his Family) would unavoidably stifle in the very birth, their and your desires, made known in your severall Remonstrances, Declarations, and Engagements (for the well-being, freedome, and safety of the people) which have since been sealed with so much of the Saints and others bloud. But after all this, your Protector to satisfie his desire of Domination, and the better to keep down that honest spirit (in those Members who were turned out
of the Little Parliament) from going on in the work of Christ, and would not submit to mans interest, hath by his Arbitrary power and force, Contrary to these Acts and Engagements, and other Laws of the Land, and the true intent and spirit of Remonstrances, and Declarations, &c. And without the desires, approbation, and Consent of the well affected of the Nation, broken down, and trampled upon the Supream Authority the peoples Represent • rs, and usurpt their power and Trust into his own hand, and having thus exalted himself on the ruines of the Nations rights and freedome, he is become guilty of High Treason; And for lesse than this, Strafford and Canterbury lost their Heads.
And as by these Acts, so also be an Engagement drawn up and sent out by that Parliament about that time, for all in the Nation (who were concerned) to signe, which runs, &c.
I do hereby declare and promise to be true and faithfull to the Commonwealth of England, as now establish without a King and house of Lords.

div.head: Annot.
div.p: Your Protector being then Lievtenant Generall, and the Army stood by upholding the Parliament in the foregoing Acts and this Engagement, and pleaded strongly that such as refused to signe it might suffer, and many Ministers with others, suffered in their estates and otherwise, for not signing of it: Besides this it was sent to the severall Regiments both of horse and foot in the Army to be signed and sealed, and was done accordingly, as a publique Testimony and Declaration they intended not to set up themselves in the same things, they had so condemned and cast out in e • hers.

div.head: In a Declaration of the English Army upon their March into Scotland 19. July 1650.
div.p:
Page 5. We were engaged in a Warr with the late King for the Defence of our Religion and Liberties, &c. Nothing l • sse would satisfie him, than to have it in his own power, to destroy Religion, and Liberties, the subversion whereof he had often attempted; that he was a man guilty of more innocent bloud in England, Scotland, and Ireland (even of those he ought to have preserved as a Father his Children) than any of his Predecessors, or we think than any History mentioneth, the guilt whereof he brought upon his Family, by solemne appeales to God: That the Sonne did tread in the Fathers st • ps and pursue his designes, destructive to Religion and Liberty: That
a party in Parliament, false to God & their trust, were willing, & did endeavour, to betray the Cause into the late Kings hands. That a remaining Party desiring to be true to God and to the people that entrusted them, out of integrity of heart, and fearing that the high displeasure of God would fall upon them if they had not done it, did bring to justice, and cause to be executed the said King; did reject the person now with you; did lay aside the House of Lords (an Estate not representing the people, nor trusted with their Liberties, yet at that time very forward to give up the peoples Rights, and obstruct what might save them, and alwayes apt enough to joyn with Kingly interest, against the peoples Liberties, whereof we wish you have not like sad experience) and did for the good of the people, Resolve the Government into a Common-wealth, &c.

Page 9. We reckon it no Breach, but a Religious keeping of the Covenant according to the equity thereof, when our Parliament for Religion and Liberties sake, and the interest of the people, did remove the King and Kingship.

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
And hath not your Generall assumed the very same and greater power to himself, to the subversion of the peoples Liberties, which the King in his often attempting to uphold himself in, shed so much innocent bloud in that day. And if that party in the Old Parliament, who would have closed with the Kings interest against the peoples Liberties, were false to God, his Cause, and the Trust committed to them; then they of the Little Parliament were so, who left their fellow-Members in th • House, and ranne away with their pretended power to your Generall, and so will all those be that hereafter shall approve of, and confirme his Ʋsurpation. And if they were true to God, and their Trust, who opposed the King in his Tyranny, and brought him to justice; and endeavoured to provide against such Oppression and slavery for the future; then they who were turned out of the Little Parliament, were so; for they were pressing on with more refinednesse upon the same account; and so will all others be faithfull to the Lord, who upon right and spirituall principles shall op •••• Tyranny, and are true friends and assertors of all just Liberty. And if the Kingly interest and Kingship was so opposite and destructive to the peoples Libe •
ties then, and changing the Government from Kingly into a Common-wealth so much for their good; it is so now:

Hitherto you Declare and Act like the best common wealths men, and as the greatest opposers of Monarchy and haters of Tyranny; and the onely faithfull friends and Assertors of publique Liberty; and in the Declaration and
Speech comming after, you seem to forget the things behind, and to be pressing towards the advancement of Christs Kingdome, and to lay him as a foundation, not onely to Rule in our hearts; but as to the Rule and Government of the world: But comparing these high expressions with your present actions, you are so far from pressing after the Kingdome of Chri • t, that ye are not so much as good Common-wealths men; but rather like Demus, for the muck of this world and the favour of men, have forsaken these good old principles wherein the Lord so owned you, and are set down with your Protectors interest, and do uphold the same Monarchy, Tyranny and Oppression in him, which was opposed in the King with so vast an expence of bloud and treasure, to the dishonour of God and grief of his people.

div.head: In a Declaration of the Officers, and Souldiers of the English Army in Scotland, Anno 1650.
div.p: At the beginning of the great, and wonderfull workings of God, in these Nations of England and Scotland. We the under Officers, and Souldiers of the English Army now in Scotland, were most of us if not all, men of private callings, & not at all interested in matters of Publi{que} and State affairs, but yet very many of us, in whom the Lord had begun to reveal himselfe in the face of Jesus Christ, were sensible of the Antichristian Tyranny that was exercised by the late King, and his Prelates, over the Consciences, bodies and estates of the true Spiritual Church of Jesus Christ, &c. Under these sad sufferings our Souls mourned, and understanding by the manifold gracious promises in the word of God, that a time of deliverance was • xp • cted to the Church of Christ, and d • struction and ruine to Babylon; our hearts with all the truly godly in England, were exceedingly stirred up to pray to the Lord, even day and night, that he would arise to destroy Antichrist, and to save his people, &c.

• et us remember how the Lord was pleased graciously to answer the prayers of his people at that time, in their deliverance from the Army raised by the late King and his prelates, &c. insomuch that soon after Scotland s ••• in peace, &c. And England obtains a Parliament, to whom they have opportunity to complain of their gri • vances, and thorough the great goodnesse of God so constituted, that grievances are heard, and overtures made to the late King for their redresse, which was so irksome to his oppressive, Tyrannicall and bloody Spirit, that c •• gain betook himselfe to overthrow the Parliament by force, &c.
And with drawing himself from his Parliament, an appearance of a Civill warr begins, which being made known to us the inferiour Officers & Soldiers of this Army, (then in our private callings) we found our hearts extraordinarily stird up by the Lord to assist the Parliamt. against the King, being abundantly satisfied in our judgements & consciences, that we were called forth by the Lord, to be instrumentall to bring about that which was our continuall prayer to God, viz the destruction of Antichrist, and the deliverance of his Church and people. And upon this simple accompt we engaged, not knowing the deep policies of worldly States-men; and have ever since hazzarded our lives in the high places of the field (where we have seen the wonders of the Lord) against all the opposers of this wroke of Jesus Christ, &c. And having these things singly in our eye, namely the destruction of Antichrist, the advancement of the Kingdome of Jesus Christ, the deliverance, and reformation of his Church in the establishment of his O • dinances amongst them in purity according to his word, and the just civill liberties of English men, &c.

We did many of us rejoyce at the Covenant because we found in it a strain towards these ends, although some being more enlightened, did apprehend it to be so mixt with worldly Intrests, that they justly fear'd the Interest of Jesus Christ would be only pretend • d to, and the Interests of this world, yea, of Antichrist himself carried under a vizzard, as we have since had experience of, &c.

We were then powerfully convinced that the Lords purpose was to deal with the late K. as a man of blood, & being perswaded in our consciences that he & his Monarchy was one of the 10. hornes of the Beast spoken of Rev. 17.12, 13, 14, 15. And being witnesses, to so much of the innocent blood of the Saints he had shed in supporting the Beast; & considering the loud cries of the Souls of the Saints under the Alter, we were extraordinarily carried forth to desire justice upon the K. that man of blood. A • d to this purpose petitioned our Superiour Officers and the Parliament to bring him to justice, &c. When God executes his judgments upon malefactors let none go about to resist, when he brings forth these his enemies that will not suffer Jesus Christ in the midst of his Saints, and breaks them in pieces like a Potters v • ssell, let not Scotland nor any other Nation say what doest thou, &c. The Lord that sees the secrets of all hearts, knowes the compliance of Scotland with the late Kings issue now with you, was in order to disturb the peace of England, for being Gods executioners upon a bloody Tyrant, and a supporter of the Throne of the Beast, &c.

But if there be any that have taken councell together against the Lord, and against his annointed whom the Lord hath decreed to set upon his holy hill of Syon, we are perswaded the Lord hath brought us hither as Instruments, thorough which he will speak to them in his wrath and vex them in his sore displeasure. We desire it may be known to you our Brethren of Scotland, that we are not Souldiers of fortune, we are not merely the servants of men, we have not only proclaimed Jesus Christ the King of Saints, to be our King by profession; but desire to submit to him upon his own termes, and to admit him to the exercise of his Royall Authority in our hearts, and to follow him wheresoever he goes, he having of his own good will entered into a Covenant of grace wi • h his poore Saints, and be assured it is he that leadeth us into Scotland, as he hath done in England and Ireland; and threfore we do in the Spirit of Brotherly love, and of the fear of the Lord beseech you to look about you, for our Lord Jesus is comming amongst you, us a refiners fire and sullers sope; and blessed are those in whom the least dram of sincerity shall be found. We have Paper directed to us from the people of Scotland, wherein we are first desired to consider the lawfulnes of our marching into Scotland. We blesse God we did that before we came, and are abundantly satisfied that we are brought hither by the Lord, nay many of us lying under temptations of flesh & blood, & going about to frame excuses to take us from this march, found that to have stayed behind, had been to have turned our backs upon Jesus Christ and to have deprived our selves of much sweet Communion with God, that now thorough his goodnesse we do enjoy, &c.

It is our prayer daily that those that fear the Lord, in England and Scotland may become one in the hand of the Lord, and joyn together in the advancement of th • Kingdome of Jesus Christ, & throwing down & tr • mpling upon the seat of the Beast. Why should not Scotland as well as England rejoyce to see the horns of the Beast cut off, that we may joyn together to hate the Whore, and burn her flesh with fire, &c. We dare not any of us though tempted thereto by your Papers, be so carnally wise, as to desert the cause and worke of Jesus Christ, in which we have been hitherto so long and so miraculously carried on: Do you think we are men so weakly principled, as to be perswaded without the least strength of argument to desert the Interest of our own Nation, and expose thousands of the precious Saints of Jesus Christ to be trampled upon as dirt in the streets, when the Lord is about to put on their beautifull garments, and to make them a praise in the earth, &c.

And thus we have in the naked plainnesse of our Soules opened our hearts unto you our dear Brethren that fear the Lord in Scotland,
where ever you be found, whether in the highest Councills or the meanest Cottages, who though you now be scattered the Lord in his due time will bring you together & bind you up as his Jewells, & make you one with those that fear the Lord among us; which the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, and in him our God and our Father bring to passe in his due time, and in the mean time make you & us wise to understand the things that concerne the exalting of Christs Kingdome, and that in all things we may be subservient to the affairs of Jesus Christ, and above all things take heed how we stir up any of the powers or strength of this world to destroy one another, &c.

closer.dateline: From the Leagure at Musleborough August 1. 1650.

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
If that the King and Bishops exercising their Tyrannicall will and power over the Consciences, bodies and estates of the people of God, contrary to Scripture and such Laws of the Land as are good, was a part of that Antichristian yoke which is promised shall wholy be destroyed, and for fulfilling whereof your hearts were so stirred up to pray unto him, and those prayers so graciously answered, in delivering the good people of Scotland from that Antichristian Army raised to force this Tyranny upon them; and in Englands obtaining a Parliament for redresse of their grievances, and the Kings endeavouring by force to overthrow them instead of giving redresse therein, such an evidence of a tyrannnicall oppressing, and Antichristian spirit, which so stirred up your hearts to assist the Parliament against him: And your thus pleading for Liberty in opposition to Tyranny, an engaging in the work of Christ against Antichrist. And if upon this simple accompt you engaged and ventured your lives in the high places of the field, and had such a presence of the Lord with you against those opposers of the work of Jesus Christ; And were so powerfully convinced, that the King as a Monarch was one of the ten hornes of the Beast; and that the Lords purpose was to deal with him as a man of bloud, and as standing upon that foundation as followes in your Declaration: What letteth then but that such (who have the same Spirit for Christ against Antichrist, as here you do expresse) may upon the very same grounds forsake their Callings, and as one man joyn themselves together to assist the Lord Jesus against your Generall, who hath wrested (as we may say) out of the hands of Christ and his Saints, all the power and fruit of all our victories, bloud and treasure expended against that bloudy Tyrant. Is not their Call as clear and just to assist Christ against Cromwell a very Jugler (to use his own words) as for you to assist the Parliament against Charles Stuart; doth not the Cry of
your Bretherens Bloud from under the Alter, slain in opposing Charles, Cry as loud against Cromwell that hath actually bereaved us of our Liberties, as against Charles that would have d • ne it? Besides the many thousands at Hispaniola, Jamica, and the Fleet, which have perished in a coveteous designe after the Spanish Treasure; and some faithfull servants of the Lord still kept in Prison against the Law of God, Nature, and Nations, for no other cause but pressing after the bringing forth these good things leading towards the advancement of Chri • ts Kingdome, and to what it shall be when the Law goes forth of Syon, Micha 4.2. which in these glorious words you seem so much to plead for; and for bearing their Testimony against your Generall, who contrary to this and other Declarations is set down up • n the Antichristian foundation of the late Monarch, which your selves confesse one of the ten Horns and a supporter of the seat of the Beast whose deadly wound he hath now healed; and do not wonder we say so, for it is not the most emminent Saint in the world standing upon this foundation, that can excuse him from being a Horn of the Beat, or that from being the Beasts foundation; neither can such a one (let him use his utmost endeavour) keep from shedding the bloud of the Saints, because as there is a natu • all enmity planted by the Lord in their hearts against the Beast, from whence they can never let him be at rest, so this persecuting bloudy spirit is entayld and shall successively remain upon th • fourth Monarchy, till the Ancient of dayes sits, and the Saints poss • sse the Kingdome, Dan. 7.21, 22. When therefore the Lord shall execute judgement upon this grand Malefactor, let none go about to resist, for the Lord will if he repent not, bring him forth amongst other his enemies that will not suffer Jesus Christ to be King in the midst of his Saints, and break him in pieces like a Potters vessell; and let not England, Scotland, nor any other Nation, nor the Army say, what doest thou? &c. The Lord that sees the secrets of all hearts, will shortly discover and unv • il your Generalls secret desi • nes, so that it shall appear to all the world he is a self-seeker and a supporter of the seat of the Beast. And therefore such as together with him, shall take counsell against the Lord, and against his Anoynted whom he hath decreed to set upon his holy hill of Zyon, we are perswaded the Lord will (as you said of your selves) bring his faithfull company together as instruments through whom he will speak to them in his wrath, and vex them in his sone displeasure: And be it know • to you Collonells, Commanders and others in England, Scotland, and Ireland, that when such do come forth, they will not be Souldiers of fortune, nor in the least the servants of men; but of ou • Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, the King of Saints and Nations, who will then be declared to be their King; and will desire to submit to him upo • h • s own terms, and to be ruled by his just and righteous
Laws: And therefore you are desired in the spirit of brotherly love and fear of the Lord to look about you, and take heed of siding with any interest against our Lord Jesus Christ, who as formerly to the Scots, is now comming amongst you as a Refiners fire and Fullers soape, to call you to an account and to redeem his blessed Cause and Interest, which you do d • spise and cast out after your so highly declaring for it; and as you said to th • m in that day, so may it be said to you, assure your selves that where the Lord finds most truth, sincerity and uprightnesse of heart, there he will be. And if when they are called to this work, they find flesh and bloud (as you did then) going about to frame excuses to take them off, and a desire rather to sit still because of the danger and difficulties that lies before them, and at the same time the Lord rousing up their spirits according to Numb. 23.24. in the sense of the dishonour brought to his Name and Cause, and Conscience on the other hand checking and telling them this backwardness is to save their bodies and purses, and the Lord also withdrawing his presence upon the account of their backwardnesse, and if they find such workings as these in their hearts, may it not be as great a discovery that it is the will of the Lord, they should up and be doing, as it was to you when the same workings (as you here say) were upon your hearts, when called forth against the good people of Scotland, and if they decline herein when the Lord thus goes before them, do they not as much turn their backs upon Jesus Christ, as you should have done if you had declined going against Scotland in that day. It is our hearty desire and daily prayer, that all those who fear the Lord in England, Scotland and Ireland, may become one in the hands of the Lord, and (for avoiding effusion of bloud) joyn together in advancing the Kingdome of Christ, and throwing down and trampling upon the seat of this Beast; and why should not you as well as w • rejoyce to see the Horns of the Beast cut off? But if after this Brotherly admonition you still resolve to uphold your Gen • rall in his Apostacy, and bloud be shed upon this account, then consider whether you do not shed the bloud of the Saints, in supporting the seat of the Beast, aswell as the King and his followers did, and thereby declare your selves (notwithstanding your high profession for the Kingdome of Christ against th • Beast) to be acted by the spirit of those Captains and Mighty men Rev. 19.17, 18 whose flesh is appointed to the fowles of the ayre, for their opposing of Jesus Christ and his followers.

div.head: In a Declaration of the Army after the Old Parliament was dissolved, 1653.
div.p:
We judged it necessary and agreed upon it, that the supream Authority should be by Parliament divolved upon known persons, men
fearing God and of approved integrity and the Government committd to them for a time, as the most hopefull way to encourage and countenance all Gods people, reforme the Law, and administer justice impartially; hoping thereby the people might forget Monarchy, and understanding their true interest in the Election of successive Parliaments, may have the Government settled upon a true Bassis without hazzard to this glorious Cause or necessitating to keep up Armes for the defence of the same, &c.

div.head: Annot.
div.p: According to these desires and the great satisfaction of the publique-spirited people of the Nation, the supream Authority (though not by Parliament) was divolved into the hands of such persons (some of them at least) as here you mention, who were reforming the Law, administring justice impartially, and doing many other good things; and did so encourage and countenance the Lords people whilest th • y sa • , as they can tell you (and so will your selves say) that they and you never so rejoyced before nor since: And when they were earnestly approving their hearts to the Lord herein, your Generall out of an itching desire of domination turns them out, assuming the Monarchicall power to himself; thereby reviving that ac • ursed thing, it here pretended the people should forget; diverting the fruit of all the bloud and treasure expended in this glorious Cause to his own lust; and hindering the faithfull people, who have not forfeited their liberty from settling the Government upon a true Bassis, to the great endangering another Warr.

div.head: Here followes some Remarkable Passages in a Speech made by Generall Cromwell, in his own name and the names of the Officers of the Army to the Members of the Little Parliament, in the Councill Chamber, before their sitting; as much, or more worthy to be observed than any thing going before, there being (among other things) a Declaration of the Armies principles, wound up to the height, as also of their proceedings, from the time they came from Worcester, till the Old Parliament was dissolved.
div.p:
Page 1. 2. After divers turnings of ass • yes, it pleased God much about the midst of this warr to winnow the forces of this Nation, and to put them into the hands of men of other principles, than those that did engage at first &c. Those strange windings and
turnings of providence, those very great appearances of God in crossing the designes of men, that he might raise up a contempa •• ble company of men not verst in Military affairs, nor having much naturall propensity to them through the owning a principle of godlines; which so soon as it came to be owned, and the State of affairs put upon that sort of account, how God blest them and all their undertakings you very wel • know, &c.

Page 3 The issues of those successes God was pleased to give to this Nation were very great things brought about, besides those dint • that were upon those Nations and places where they were carried on, even in the Civill affairs, to the bringing Offenders to justice; the state of of this Government to the name at least of a Common-wealth; the searching and sitting of all places and persons; the King removed and brought to Justice and many great on •• with him; the House of Commons the Representative of the people of England winnowed, sifted, and brought to a handfull, &c.

Page 4. As the effect of that Memorable Year 1648. was to lay the foundation of bringing Delinquents to punishment, so it was of the change of the Government, although it be true the carriages of some in most eminent Trust was such as would have frustrated to us the hopes of all our undertakings, by that closure that would have been endeavoured by the King, whereby we should have put • nto his hands all that cause and interest we had opposed, and had nothing to have secured us but a little piece of paper, &c.

Page 5. When I and my fellow Officers and Souldiers came from
Worcester, we expected having such a History to look back unto; a God that appeareth so eminently, so visibly; the Mercies that God had shewed; the expectation that were in the hearts of all good men, would have prompted those that were in Authority to have done those good things which might have been judged a return fit for such a God, and worthy of such Mercies, and a discharge of duty, to those for whom all these Mercies have been sh • wed; that is, the true interest of the three Nations, &c.

Page 7. Upon our return we came fully bent in our hearts to desire and use all fa • r & lawfull means we could to have had the Nation reap the fruit of all that bloud and treasure that had been expended in this Cause, and had many thirstings in our spirits to find out waies and means • o help it forward, and were very tender so much as to petition till August last, &c.

Hath the Lord begun thus in the Spirit? then surely he will not end in the flesh; i • so it would then become wisedome, if you would again expect the like appearances of God for you, and not be winnowed away as others, to keep close to, and be more refined in • h • se good old principles.

They were marvailous dispensations that made you so instrumental in those great revolutions, & in winnowing the house til it became a handful, this handfull might be thought to be wheat, but did not your Gen. desire (as sometime the Devill did Peter) to winnow them all a way, not only the Chaff, but especially the good Wheat, that so he might get into the Saddle and play Rex alone, for he hath gotten into his hand all that Cause and Interest, that some in the House (you so complain of) would have given the King, and we have not so much as a piece of paper to secure us, the Instrument (as it is called) of Government, but indeed of Tyranny, is not the result of any Capitulation between him & the people his Superiors, but a manifestation of his Arbitrary will and power forced upon us without our consent: Surely the appearances of the Lord against this Appostacy will be greater (if he repent not) than the quashing those insurrections, &c. against his worke on foot in that day.

If you really minded the peoples good more than your own advancement
as is here pretended; as you would not have turned out those honest men of the little Parliament, when they were doing these good things: So surely you would have brought forth better fruit under your new Government (after almost three years growth) than yet you have, which is now little other then the building what had been destroyed: Imprisoning the true Friends t • the Cause of Christ, and the closing with corrupt interests as the King and Presbyterians did to hold up your self in power; which is very unsutable to all the bloud and treasure expended in this glorious Cause or that blessed spirit you here seem to be acted by.

Page 8. Finding the people dissatisfied in every corner of the Nation, and bringing home to our doors the non-performance of those thi • gs that had been promised, we did think our selves concerned to keep up the Reputation of honest men in the world, and therefore we had divers times endeavoured a Meeting with divers Members of Parliament, &c. We had at the least ten or twelve Meetings beseeching them to do those things that had been promi • ed, that so it might appear they did not do th • m by any suggestion from the Army, but of
their own ingenuities, &c. declaring plainly that the issue would be the judgement of God against them, the dissatisfaction of the people, and the putting things into confusion, &c. When we saw things would not be laid to heart, we considered amongst our selves what other way to have recourse unto, and when we came unto those close considerations, they began to take the Act of the New Representative to heart, and seemed exceeding willing to put it on, the which had it been done, or would it have been done with that integrity, that would have saved this cause, and the interest we have been so long engaged in, there could nothing have happened to our judgements, more welcome than that would have been.

div.head: Annotat.
div.p:
The good people of the Nation are as much dissatisfied now as then, though through your frighting them with Prisons, &c. they dare not bring home to your d • ores the non-performance of former promises, why should you not thnebe, be as frequent in your meetings now as then, and never cease til you had redeemed the good old Cause, with you selv • s and the free-borne people of the Nation from this new contrived servitude under a Protector, whose intendment as to perpetuate himself, and men of that Spirit, to Lord it over us, which is more destructive to the peoples liber
• ies, than the provisson the Parliament
would have made for a new Representative or the perpetuating themselves was like to have be.

Page 13. When we saw their intendment was to perpetuate themselves, and men of that spirit, for some had it from their own mouthes, This was a high breach of trust, if they had been a Parliament never violated, sitting as free and as clear as ever any sat in England, yet if they would go about to perpetuate themselves, we did think this to be so high a breach of Trust, as greater could not be, &c.

div.head: Annot.
div.p: If it were so high a breach of trust for the Parliament, who were chosen by the people, to perpetuate themselves: Then its High Treason in your Generall to do so, he being but a Ʋsurper, and forces his power upon us without our consent.

Page 15. But seeeing they would not give us that which might satisfie us that their way was honest, and safe, they would give us leave to make our Objection; we did t • ll them that we thought that way they were going in would be impracticable, we could not tell them how it would be brought to p • sse, to send out an Act of Parliament into the Countrey, to have Qualifications of an Act to be the Rules of Electors, and Elected, and not to know who should execute this; desired to know whether the next
Parliament were not like to consist of all Presbyters, whether those Qual • fications would hinder them or Nuters, & though it be our desires to value and esteem of that judgement, onely they having as we know disserted this Cause and interest, upon the Kings accompt, and upon that closure between them and the Neighbouring Nation, we do think we must professe, we had as good have delivered up our Cause into the hands of any, as into the hands of interested and Byast men, &c. But answer was made by a very • mminent person at the same time as before, that nothing would save the Nation, but the continuance of this Parliament, &c.

div.head: Annot.
div.p:
You pretend you dissolved the Old Parliament because they made such hast with the Act for a new Rep e •• ntative, and did not assure you the Qualifications contained therein were so just and honest, as to keep out Presbyters and Neuters; and do say that to place the power so, was to threw away the Cause and the Nations Liberties, into the hands of Interested and Byast men wh • never bled for it. And that the onely way of sa • ety to the Cause, was to commit the Trust to persons of Hon ur and integrity; well-affected to Religion and the interest of the Nation.
A second thing why they were dissolved was, because they went to perpetuate themselves: Yet notwtihstanding these fine pretences, the greatest part of your Protectors first Parliament (so called) were Presbyters, Neuters, or worse; and the second are as bad and worse than the former. This compared with his perpetuating his power upon us, he so complained of in the Old Parliament, declares plainly that he dissolved them rather to get the power into his own hand, than for the preservation of the Cause; and that he is false (as in many other things so) to this honest principle he here so much pretends to.

Page 16. The Government bring in that condition as it was, and things being under so ill sense abroad, and so likely to come to confusion in every respect if it went on so; we desired they would divolve the Trust over to persons of Honour and integrity, that were well known, men well-aff • cted to Religion and the interest of the Nation; which we told them and was confest, was no new thing, when these Nations had been under distractions, &c. We desired them to lay these things seriously to heart; They told us they would take consideration of them till morning; that they would sleep upon them, &c. At the parting, 2. or 3. of the chiefest did tell us, they would suspend proceedings with the Representative the next day, ti • l they had further conference; and we did acquesse, &c. The next morning we considering how to order what we had to offer to them when they were to meet in the evening, word was brought, they were proceeding with a Representative with all the eagerness they could, and had brought it to that issue, with that hast that it had never been before; leaving out the things that did necessarily relate to due qualifications, resolved to make it a paper Bill, not to ingrosse it, that they might make the quicker dispatch of it; thus to have thrown all the liberties of the Nation into the hands that never bled for it: Upon this account we thought it our duty not to suffer it; and upon this the house was dissolved.

This we tell you, that so you may know that what hath been done in dissolving this Parliament, was as necessary as the preservation of this Cause; and that necessity that led us to do that, hath brought us to this issue of exercising an extraordinary way and course, of drawing your selves together upon this account, that you are men who know the Lord, and have made observations of his marvailous dispensations, and may be trusted with this Cause, &c. having done that upon this ground of necessity which we know was not feigned, but reall and true, to the end that the government might not be at a losse, and that we might manifest to the world the singleness of our hearts and integrity, who did those things not to grasp after the power, our selves to keep it in a Military hand, no not for a day, as far as God enable us with strength and ability to put it in the hands that might be called from severall parts of the Nation, &c. this necessity, this integrity of labouring to divest the sword of the power and Authority in the civil Administration of it hath been that, that hath moved us to conclude of this course.

Truly God hath called you to this work by (I think) as wonderfull providences, as ever past upon the Sons of men in so short a time; and truly taking the argument
of necessity for the Government must not fall, take the appearances of the will of God in this thing, I am sure you would have been loath it should have been resigned into the hands of wicked men, and enemies; I am sure God would not have it so, it comes therefore to you by way of necessity; it comes to you by the way of the wise providence of God, though • hrough weak hands, &c. I shall remember you of one Scripture which hath been much upon my spirit, Hosea 11.12. Yet Judah ruleth with God, and is faithfull with the Saints, &c. It is said before, Ephraim did compasse God about with lyes, and Israell with deceipt; how God hath been compassed about with fastings and thanksgivings, and other exercises, and tentations, I think we have all to lament; why truly you are called by God to be faithfull with the Saints, who have been somewhat instrumentall to your Call, He that ruleth over men (the Scripture saith) must be just, ruling in the fear of God, &c.

div.head: Annot.
div.p: You here hold forth that the many wonderfull appearances of the Lord for his people in the late Warrs, was that evill men and such as were not faithful with the Saints, and suited to the work might be laid aside, and that godly wen and men of principles, who knew the Lord and had made observations of his marvailous dispensations, might be called to Rule with him, as being most lively to carry on his work, and most fit to be entrusted with his Cause; in order to this its pretended the old Parliament was dissolved and the little Parliament called, as men principled to bring forth these good things, which the former by their fastings and other exercises, did but lye to the Lord in, and did not do, and that the Government might not fall into th • hands of wicked men and Presbyters; as also to manifest to the world, you did not these things to grasp after the power your selves, or to keep it in a Military hand, no not for a day; this is your pretence: But doth not the mixing of that Assembly (above mentioned (knowingly) with contrary interests, and the turning out of them who were doing this good, and the greatest part of your Generalls Parliaments being Presbyters, Neuters, and worse (not near so good as the old Parliament he so complains of) hold clearly, that all these pretended necessities (as to him) were of his own making, and but as so many blindes to cover his designe of exalting himself.

Page 21. I think I need as little advise you about propogation of the Gospell, and encourageing such Ministers and such a Ministry as be faithfull in the Land, upon whom the true Character is, men that have truly received the spirit for such a use, as Christians will be well able to discern and do, &c. Page 22. I speak not it is far from my heart, for a Ministry deriving it selfe thorough the P • p • sie, and and pretending to that which is so much insisted upon to be succession: the true succession is through the Spirit, given in that measure as the Spirit is given, and that is a right succession, &c.

I confesse I never lookt to see such a day as this, it may be nor
you, when Jesus Christ shall be owned as he is this day: Jesus Christ is owned this day by you all, by your willingness in appearing here, and you manifest this as farre as poor creatures can, to be a day of the power of Christ, &c.

Having through so much blood and tryalls as have been upon these Nations, made this to be one of the great issues thereof, to have a people called to the Supream Authority upon an avowed accompt God hath owned his Sonne by this; and you by your willingnesse do own Jesus Christ; and therefore for my part, I confesse I did never look to see such a light; we have not allowed our selves in the choice of one person in whom we had not this good hope, that there was faith in Jesus Christ and love unto all the Saints: And thus God hath owned you, and by your coming together have you owned him, &c.

You are as like the forming of God as ever a people were, if any man should ask you, and tender a Book to you, you will dare to swear that neither directly, nor indirectly did you seek to come hither, you have been p • ssive in coming hither, &c. Consider the Circumstances by which you are Called, through what Difficulties; through what st • ivings; through what bloud you are come, hither, &c. I say nev • r a p • rple form'd for such a purpose (so Called) if it were time to compare your standing with those that have been called by the suffer • ges of the people, who can tell you how soon God can fit the people for such a thing; and who would
desire any thing more in the world, but that it might be so? I would that all the Lords people were Prophets! I would they were fit to be called, or fit to call! And it i • the longing of our hearts to see them once own the Interest of Jesus Christ. What a duty will lye upon you to have your Conversation such, as that they may love you; that they may see you lay out your time and spirit for them: Is not this the most likely way to bring them to their liberties?
