And do you not by this put i • up n God to stode the time and the season for it, by pouring forth his spirit, at least by convincing them that as men fearing God, have fought them out of their thraldome and bondage under the legall power; so men fearing God, rule them in the fear of God, and take care to administer good things unto them? &c.

div.head: Annot.
div.p: You here pretend to have a great care of those who receive their Ministry from the spirit, and that its far from your heart to speak for the Nationall Clergy, who deriving their standing through the Papacy, you say is a false Succession: But now the tide is so turned, that the encouragement, or disencouragement is upon the owning, or not owning your Generalls Ʋsurpt power; for though men be never so spirituall and able to teach, and th s known before hand, yet if out of consci • nce they cannot how to be examined by the T • yers (that Image of the Beast▪) then that encouragement they formerly had upon this accompt is taken away, though they and their Families perish; whilest the others submitting to them are encouraged, to hale the people of God and others to prisons for not putting into their mouths; and yet you are so impudent as to tell us, you are not at all changed from what you were when you spake these words.

By these words you declare you were forgetting things behind and pressing
towards the Kingdome of Christ, and to act as upon his foundation, so in his Name; and therefore judged it your duty to choose none but Believers, who had love to all the Saints as being most suitable to that Kingdome. But comparing these words with present actions, there is just ground to say, that you who did thus pretend to begin in the spirit, are ending in the flesh; and condemning that good way you here seem to approve of.

And if their being Saints and neither directly nor indirectly seeking to come into power but were c • lled by others was, such a manifestation they were formed of God: Then who formed them, who sued to this party and the other, wooing and disiring them to make parties for them, and using other indirect means; as giving money to some, and paying the Boat hire and charges, &c. of others, and • ending in whole Beeves, Mutt • n Venison Pasties, Wine, &c. to encourage the people to chuse them; and this done in a wicked disorderly manner, to the great dishonour of God, the grief of his people and the further prejudice of his glorious Cause; surely it is very unlikely that such persons as these should own the Interest of Jesus Christ, or bring the
people to their liberties, but rather to be slaves and vassals to your Protectors Interest, which unworthy carriage of his, in suffering things to go in this way after such glorious words for Jesus Christ, can be tearmd no other but wofull back sliding, which the Lord without eminent repentance will charge home upon him.

I say you are called with a high call, and why should we be afrayd to say or think that this may be the doore to usher in things, that God hath promised, and prophesi • d of, and to set the hearts of his people to wait for and expect; we know who they are that shall warr with the Lamb, aginst his enemies, they shall be a people called, chosen & faithfull, and hath in the Millita • y way, I believe you know it, he hath acted with them, and for them, and now in the civill power and Authority, & these are not ill prognostications of that good we wait for & expect, I do think some thing is at the doore, we are at the threshold, and therefore it becomes us to lift up our heads, and to encourage our selves in the Lord, and we have some of us thought it our du • y, not vainly looking at the prophesie in Dan. 2.44. And the Kingdome shall not be delivered to another people. Truly God hath brought it into your hands by his owning, and bl • ssing, and calling out a Millitary power, God hath perswaded their hearts to be instrumentall in calling you, and this hath been set upon our hearts, and upon all the faithfull in the land, it may be it is not our duty to deliver it over to any other people, and that Scripture may be fulfilling now to us; but I may go beyond my time.

But I thanke God I have my hopes exercised in these things, and so I am perswaded are yours; truly seeing things are so that you are at the edge of the promises, & prophesies, at least if there were n • ither promise for this nor prophesy, your coveting the best things, endeavouring after the best things, and as I have said elsewhear if I wear to chuse the meanest
Officer in the Army, or Common-wealth, I would chuse a godly man that hath principles, especially where trust is to be committed, for I know where to have a man of principles: I believe if any of you should chuse a servant you would do so, and I would all our Magistrates were so chosen, that may be some effects of this, it is our duty to chuse men that fear the Lord, to praise the Lord, yea such as the Lord formes for himselfe, and he expects not prayses from others. This being so, it puts me in minde of an other Scripture, Mal. 6.8. which indeed is a glorious prophesy, and I am perswaded of the Gospell, or it may be of the Jews, also there it is prophesied he will bring his people again out of the depths of the Sea, as once he led Israell through the red Sea, and it may be some doe think God is bringing the Jewes home to their station from the Isles of the Sea. Surely when God sets up his Gospell-Church, it shall be gathering people out of deep waters, out of the multitude of waters, such are his people drawn out of the multitude of Nations and people of the world, and that Psalm will be very glorious in many other parts of it.

When he gave the Word great was the company of them that publisht it, Kings of the Arm • es did fly a pace, and shee that tarryed at home devided the spoyle, and although ye have layen among the potts, yet shall ye be as the wings of a dove covered with silver, and her feathers with yellow gold. And indeed the triumph of t • at Psalm is exceeding high and great, and God is accomplishing it, and the close of it, that closeth with my heart, and I am perswaded will with yours also. That God makes Hills and Mountains and they reel, and God hath a Hill too, and his Hill is as the Hill of Bashan, and the Charriots of God are 20000. of Angells, and God will dwell upon this hill for ever. All that I have to say in my own, and in the name of my fellow Officers (who have joyned with me in this worke) that we shall commend you to the grace of God, and to the guidance of his Spirit, having thus farre served you or rather our Lord Jesus Christ in it; we are as we hope and shall be ready in our stations, according as the providenc • of God shall lead us, to be subservient to the work of God and the Authority which we reckon God hath set over us. And although we have no formall thing to present you with, to which the hands and outward visible expressions of the hearts of the Officers of the three Nations are set, yet we may say for them, and we may say also with confidence that our Brethren at Sea, with whom neither in Scotland, nor Ireland, nor at Sea hath any ar • ifice been used, to perswade their approb • tions to this work; yet we can say that their consent and affections hath flowed in to us b • yond our expectations, and
we may say with all confidence that we have had their approbation • and full consent unsought indeed to the other work; so that you have their hearts and affections in this; and not onely they, but we have very many Papers from the Churches of God throughout the Nation, wonderfully both approving what hath been done in removing obstacles, and approving what hath been done in this very thing.

div.head: Annot
div.p:
In the latter part of this Speech you may take notice what g • orious wordes you have spoken for the kingdome of Christ, and that glory which is to be revealed in the latter dayes, and what encouragement you give the Saints to believe that the little Stone had been at worke already, or was nigh its comming for • h as in that quoted place, Dan. 2.44. And that something was at the Door • , that we w • re at the very edge and Threshold of the Prophesie and Promises being fulfilled, and that God was bringing home the Jews to their station from the Isl • of the Sea, and what shakings of Mountains and Hills there will be, when this work comes forth; and do exhort us to lift up our heads in the expectation hereof, and to encou • age our s lv • s in the Lord: And though there were neither promise nor prophesy to be fulfilled, yet it was our duty, to covet, and endeavour after the best things, and to be as refined and spirituall as is possible in the governments of the world, as well as of particular persons, or families, it being a • uty to chuse men who fear the Lord to praise the Lord, such as he formes for himself, and he expects not praises f • om others: and you pretend to put th • se principles into practice in calling the Little Parliament together; in chusing of whom what ever your intentions were, yet surely those who were faithfull of them, sat there in answer to the faith & prayers of those Sts. who had not defil • d their garments, but desired with more refinedness to act up to their former Ʋirgin principles, & those promises, &c. then made to the Lord & his p • ople in the daies of our streghits: And also had the approbation of those mentiond in the end of the speech without any artifi •• used to pe • swade them • hereto; & whilest they sat th • re was a generall rejoycing among all go • d men whose hearts went along w •• h the work of God in that da • ; and th • o • e • Off e • s and Souldiers durst speak their minds freel • , and encourage one anoth • r in these honost principles, and to oppose Tyranny and wi • k • dnesse where ever they saw it, and we • e growing up a mai • in these glorious things, and attained to such a blessed frame of • i it, as to be willing to follow the Lord into F ance, Spain, Rom • ▪ or where ever he h • d any work for them to • o: And as it was a day of joy to the good people, so it was of terrour and sadnesse to t • e loose Clergy, Lawyers and the wicked of our own and the Nations abroad, every one wonde • ing and looking what would be the end of th • t glorious pr • sence we had then among us. But since your Generall and you with him, declined from these honest principles, and turned those honest men before mentioned
out of the Listle Parleament, who were going on in the worke, according to these honest principles; and usurpt the power into his own hand he had so declared against, and sat down upon the seat of the Beast, and fell a persecuting some and imprisoning other of the Saints, and to blaspheme • he Lords Spirit, in saying, they were acted by the Spirit of the Devill, for no other cause the Lord knowes, but their faithfulnesse to him in pressing after these very things you here so much declare for, and opposing your back sliding, and building what had been destroyed: Now since you came to do these wi • ked things, this glorious presence which was then with you is departed, as appears in his, as eminently blasting your designes now, as ever he bl •• t you before, witnesse your great defeat and disappoyntment at Hyspaniola, the losse of some thousands of men at Jamica, the in succesfulnesse of the Fleet in the Straights these two years together, the courage of the enemy heightened, the great losses and cowardlinesse of your men in the N • rrow Seas, the corrupt Interests before mentioned lifting up their heads, and rejoycing the Nations abroad, contemning and scorning us. The lively Spirit which was once in the Army now choakt and lost, the hearts of the Saints which were formerly with you, now grieved and engaged against you; and to add to this the blessed Cause and wo • ke of Christ is stopped and hindered: All which considered it is high time you awake out of this back-sl • ding state, and break off your sins by r • pentance, and walking with more refinednesse than ever, according to your good old p • inciples, and thereby redeem the almost three years time you have now lost, that so the Lords former presence may again be with you if he shall please to use you any further in his worke; in ord • r to which, repair to you • Gene • all, and endeavour all you can to convince him of his evill (if that be yet to do) and when you have done so (after humbling himselfe before the Lord and his people) to go to that very place at W • stminster where he tooke up his new contrived dignity (that child of his sorrow) and to throw down and trample upon his Chayr of State, and all that pomp and bravery prepared for that s • l • mnity; and to declare before the Lord, his people, and the Nation, his sorrow and unfeigned repentance, as for other things, so for persecuting his Brethren, whom he made once believe was as dea • to him as his own Soul, and for no other cause then is above mentioned: As olso for his taking upon him that accursed thing (the Monarchicall Government with its oppurtenances) which himsel • e with • thers had declared and witnessed against, with so vast an expence of blood and treasure, and had been so in trumental to destroy: If ever it be well with you, there must be some kind or other of manifest reall repentance, because the dishonour which hath been brought upon the Name and wayes of God h • th been so publique, and there is nothing less can help him, for the wound he hath received from the Lord in endeavouring to heal the deadly wound of the Beast is so great, that all the renewed change of his Parliament, or Presbyterian plaister, nor any other dawing
means he shall use can heal it, for the Lord hath so appointed that onely they who confesse, and forsake their sins shall have mercy: The which if the Lord of his grace shall please to work in him and you, would exceedingly rejoyce their hearts, who have good reason to cease from man; and in all their speaking and actings in this day dersie to be found purely and alone for the advancement of the Blessed Cause and Interest of our Lord Jesus Christ.

div.head: POST SCRIPT.
div.p:
THe designe of this Collection out of the Choicest and most Materiall of the Armies Declarations, Remonstrances, &c. among other things, is chiefly to bring to your Remembrance that Excellent Frame which formerly and of late appeared to be upon the hearts of the then honest Officers and Souldiers of the English Armies till their late Declention. From the beginning of the Book till you come to the Declaration of August 1. 1650. Dated at M • stbrough in Scotland, you may see what a blessed Spirit you se • med to be acted by for the peoples Liberties against Monarchy a • d Tyranny. The three Acts and the Engagement of Parliament are added, because they are suitable to what goes before, and of your own procuring. From the fore-mentioned Declaration to the end of the Book you do carry it higher, and do seem to presse towards the advancement of the Kingdome of Jesus Christ, at least th • t you shoud be coveting and endeavouring after the B • st things. The Annotations running along by them, are in some measure to declare how, and wherein you are Declined from those honest Principles to Monarchy, Tyranny, and loosnesse, which indeed is so plain that he who runs may read it. And although most of you do acknowledge you are out of the way, and that things are not a • they ought to be; yet you sit still enjoying your pay, and endeavour all you can to muzle your Consciences, and to excuse your selves therein by saying, a Souldier is a lawfull employment; and that good men were Souldiers formerly under wicked Rulers; as if their standing and yours were all one; take heed how you wind and turn the Scriptures like a Nose of Wax to serve your lusts, for when you have done all you can it will not help you: For as that Dispensation they then were under and the present which is upon us doth differ (as your selves also Confesse in Declaration from Mustbrough before-mentioned,
where you say; the Lord was come to put on the Saints beautifull garments and to make them a praise in the Earth; to destroy the Whore and to burn her fl • sh with fire) So their being Souldiers was by a common providence, or by accident, or probably as one man is of this Calling, and another of that to get a livelihood. But were never raised up and called forth by the Lord from their private Callings, and encouraged by a Parliaments Declarations, to engage for the preservation of the peoples Liberties in opposition to Tyranny and Oppression; to dest •• y Antichrist, and for the advancement of the Kingdom • of Jesus Christ, as you have been, and have declared you engaged not herein as a Mercinary Army hired to serve the Arbitrary power of a State, nor as Souldiers of Fortune and servants of men; but out of Judgement and Conscience, upon the accompt and for the ends aforesaid as appears in Declaration 14. June, 1647. and the Declaration in Scotland before quoted, and i • you look into the Case of the Army Stated Page 4. and in the 17. Page of this Book you may see you could argue thus against Hollis and Sta • leton and that Faction, who were for the Kings Interest in that day; who you so opposed for no othe cause than that they would ••• ve given t • e King that Power and Trust your Protector hath now assum • d to himself. If this be so, then surely you cannot honestly in the least p ••• d your standing to be lawfull and good form theirs, nor upon any o h • r • ccompt whatsoever, so long as this backsliding con •• nu • s. Th p •••• cuted Cause of Christ, and his Spirit in his S • in • s in P • i • on 〈◊〉 their faithfulln • sse thereto, and to these honest Pri • ciple • , •••• s for ••• timony, and • t is t e duty of all those who have • ight i •• o th ••• things; to forsak • Father, Mother Wife, &c. Estate, yea life it • el • , and therein to follow the Lord fully whethersoever he goes; for th • Sa • n • s are to overcome the Beast and false Prophet, and • ll who are • cted by that Spi • it by th • bloud of the Lamb, the word of their Te • timony and they lived not their lives unto the death, Rev. 12.11. Therefor • i • s your duty while you keep up Armes, to endeavour to see those t ings brought forth for whi • h you took them up at first, and if you cannot by perswasion on the ou • h nd, or are not free to oppose your Protecto • on the other, as you did th • King upon the same accompt; then you are by laying down and disserting th • m, to declare you approve not of their actions, and can have no fellowship with them in these unfruitfull works of darknesse: But if notwithstanding upon worldly c • nsiderations you will yet k •• p up; then know you ar • not called by th • Lord, nor • he pe • ples Representors for the preservation of their Rights and Freedomes; and
for the advancement of the Kingdome of Christ as you were before, but are meer Mercinaries, and upholders of the same and greater Tyranny in your Protector, which hath cost so much Bloud and Treasure to oppose in the King. And if any shall yet Object and say, your way is good and we are mistaken; The answer i • , if your way were of God and according to his good will and pleasure, it would be more pure and spirituall, and for the glory of God than the Govrnment which was before it, and more agreeing with what it shall be, when the Prophesies and Promises are fulfilled, Isa. 32.1, 2. Micha 4.1, 2. Psal. 72. And to that honest spirit in the fore-going Speech you seem to be acted by: But its clearly evident you are not so, but are gone back with your Captain to those old Aegyptian practices, which you acknowledge the Lord by his wonderfull dispensations had brought you from: So that no man who approves his heart to the Lord, and is not a flattering time-server for his own advantage, can truly say you are so honest as to endeavour after the best things you so pretended to, but are gone back to Aegypt.
